urn:contentItem:5RYY-R001-JB5M-W3VC-00000-00Post Session: Quick Review2018-03-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPost Session: Quick Review

Benchmarks snap two-day gaining streak

Indian equity benchmarks traded in red throughout the day and ended with losses of over half percent, following negative cues from global stocks. Markets snapped the two-day gaining streak with Sensex and Nifty slipping below their crucial 33,000 and 10,150 levels, respectively. Markets started the session on a pessimistic note as traders remained concerned with report that Goods and Services Tax (GST) collections slid for the second straight month to Rs 851.74 billion in February as only 69 per cent of the assessees filed returns. Around 5.951 million GSTR 3B returns were filed for the month of February till March 25. Sentiments on the street weakened further with a private report stating that weak macroeconomic indicators like current account deficit and inflation have exposed India to adverse global macro developments such as US monetary policy trajectory and trade war risks. Expiry of futures and options contracts for the month of March and profit booking on the last trading day for the current financial year 2017-18 before the long term capital gains tax (LTCG) kicks in from April 2, 2018 are the other factors that weighed on the sentiments.

Traders failed to take any sense of relief with Chief Economic Advisor Arvind Subramanian's statement that he wanted a simpler GST structure. He also said that once the GST Council is confident that the revenue through indirect tax is stabilising, it will do more simplification future.

On the global front, Asian markets ended lower, as tech stocks extended losses following sell-offs of their U.S. peers overnight. The European markets were trading in red in early deals on Wednesday, as persistent concerns over a regulatory crackdown on big tech and a string of negative headlines overnight hit sentiments towards the sector that drove a long bull market.

Back home, majority of Telecom stocks ended lower after telecom secretary Aruna Sundararajan said that the merger proposal of Vodafone India and Idea Cellular, to create the country's largest telecom company, is in the final stages of approval. Besides, stocks related to IT space edged lower after the Income Tax Department freezed bank accounts and deposits of Nasdaq listed IT firm, Cognizant in Chennai and Mumbai for allegedly evading dividend distribution tax.

The BSE Sensex ended at 32957.93, down by 216.46 points or 0.65% after trading in a range of 32917.66 and 33104.11. There were 8 stocks advancing against 23 stocks declining on the index. (Provisional)

The broader indices ended in red; the BSE Mid cap index was down by 0.46%, while Small cap index was down by 0.92%. (Provisional)

The only gaining sectoral indices on the BSE were Consumer Durables up by 0.18% and Oil & Gas up by 0.04%, while Telecom down by 2.66%, Metal down by 2.14%, Basic Materials down by 1.75%, Realty down by 1.09% and Power down by 1.08% were the top losing indices on BSE. (Provisional)

The top gainers on the Sensex were Wipro up by 3.36%, Coal India up by 2.76%, Hero MotoCorp up by 2.05%, Yes Bank up by 1.12% and Indusind Bank up by 0.56%. (Provisional)

On the flip side, Bharti Airtel down by 3.52%, Adani Ports &SEZ; down by 2.92%, Tata Steel down by 2.91%, Reliance Industries down by 2.09% and Bajaj Auto down by 2.09% were the top losers. (Provisional)

Meanwhile, amid intense pricing competition among telecom companies, the ratings agency, ICRA in its latest report has said that the recovery in the telecom sector is likely to be prolonged and the companies may see the pressure on their cash flows for few more quarters.

The rating agency has said that price competition in the sector is expected to continue to remain intense as the larger operators are contesting to acquire subscribers of the exiting telcos and added that the revenues and OPBDITA of the sector may fall by 13% and 34% respectively, in financial year 2017-18 (FY2018). However, it expects recovery in revenues and profitability of telecom sector by end of financial year 2018-19 (FY2019) and is also expecting reduction in the industry debt levels to Rs 4.3 lakh crore by FY2019 from the estimation of Rs 4.7 lakh crore as on March 31, 2018, on the back of asset monetisation and increased promoter support.

Besides, on the long term basis, ICRA expects recovery in the sector, on the back of a consolidated structure, better pricing power and data usage with greater price-inelasticity. It also noted that larger telcos are getting an opportunity from the exit of smaller telcos to garner subscribers and the competition for them remains intense.

The CNX Nifty ended at 10121.25, down by 62.90 points or 0.62% after trading in a range of 10096.90 and 10158.35. There were 19 stocks advancing against 31 stocks declining on the index. (Provisional)

The top gainers on Nifty were Wipro up by 3.41%, Bosch up by 2.90%, Tech Mahindra up by 2.62%, GAIL India up by 2.43% and Hero MotoCorp up by 2.00%. (Provisional)

On the flip side, Bharti Airtel down by 3.71%, Tata Steel down by 3.35%, Vedanta down by 2.77%, Adani Ports &SEZ; down by 2.60% and Reliance Industries down by 2.02% were the top losers. (Provisional)

The European markets were trading in red; Germany's DAX decreased 139.4 points or 1.16% to 11,831.43, France's CAC was down by 52.58 points or 1.03% to 5,063.16 and UK's FTSE 100 shed 44.02 points or 0.63% to 6,956.12.

Asian stocks closed in red on Wednesday after US technology shares came under heavy selling pressure overnight on concerns about tighter industry regulations. Trade-related tensions also kept investors nervous. Japanese stocks fell, led by a sell-off in tech firms after their US counterparts skidded on concerns about government regulation, while ex-dividend trades added to the broader losses. Further, Chinese stocks closed lower, led by declines in the foreign trade sector. Stocks related to foreign trade dropped following the US government's latest tariff plan on imports from China.

urn:contentItem:5W89-NPT1-JB5M-W0N0-00000-00Post Session: Quick Review2019-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPost Session: Quick Review

Benchmarks end volatile day in red terrain

Indian equity benchmarks ended the volatile day of trade in red terrain on Tuesday, as investors awaited RBI's monetary policy decision, amid weak cues from global markets. Key indices have made a cautious start and traded marginally in red, as traders remain worried with a private report that the pre-monsoon rainfall in the country was the second lowest in 65 years. The three-month pre-monsoon season March, April and May ended with a rainfall deficiency of 25%. As per the report, all the four meteorological divisions - Northwest India, Central India, East-Northeast India and South Peninsula - recorded deficit rainfall of 30%, 18%, 14% and 47%, respectively. Selling also crept in with the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) statement that Over 6,800 cases of bank fraud involving an unprecedented Rs 71,500 crore have been reported in 2018-19. In the last 11 fiscal years, a total of 53,334 cases of fraud were reported by banks involving a massive amount of Rs 2.05 lakh crore.

Markets continued their weak run in late afternoon deals, as anxiety remained among the traders with Industry chamber, Confederation of Indian Industry's (CII) statement that the US decision to withdraw export incentives from India has been taken in a haste and would hurt the domestic exporters. CII President Vikram Kirloskar expressed hope that both the US and India would discuss the matter and find an amicable solution to this issue. However, further losses got restricted as investors found some comfort with Finance Secretary Subhash Chandra Garg's statement that declining global oil prices, stable rupee and falling interest rate are sure signs of high growth in coming months. India's growth rate has declined to 5-year low of 5.8% in the fourth quarter of the previous fiscal and 6.8% for the full financial year 2018-19. Traders took note of a report that India is forecast to overtake the UK to become the world's fifth largest economy this year and projected to surpass Japan to feature at the second position in the Asia-Pacific region by 2025. It added the economic outlook 'looks positive' for the second term of Modi government, with GDP growth forecast to average around 7 per cent per year over the 2019-2023 period.

On the global front, Asian markets ended mostly lower on Tuesday in cautious trade as worries about rising trade tensions and impact on global economic growth sapped risk appetite. European markets were trading in green, after the euro area unemployment rate dropped to the lowest since 2008 in April. The figures from Eurostat showed that the unemployment rate came in at 7.6 percent versus 7.7 percent in March. Back home, the power sector stocks were in focus with global ratings agency Moody's Investors Service's statement that the increasing share of renewables in the total energy mix of the country may lead to an increase in regulatory risk for coal-based projects in the long term.

The BSE Sensex ended at 40121.65, down by 145.97 points or 0.36% after trading in a range of 40031.05 and 40312.07. There were 14 stocks advancing against 17 stocks declining on the index.

The broader indices ended in red; the BSE Mid cap index fell 0.15%, while Small cap index was down by 0.21%.

The top gaining sectoral indices on the BSE were Capital Goods up by 0.38%, Utilities up by 0.30%, Metal up by 0.29%, Telecom up by 0.24% and Industrials up by 0.13%, while IT down by 1.55%, TECK down by 1.44%, Oil & Gas down by 0.88%, Healthcare down by 0.87% and Basic Materials down by 0.81% were the top losing indices on BSE.

The top gainers on the Sensex were Yes Bank up by 2.51%, Axis Bank up by 1.48%, NTPC up by 1.47%, Coal India up by 1.32% and Vedanta up by 1.25%.

On the flip side, Hero MotoCorp down by 3.11%, TCS down by 2.46%, Asian Paints down by 2.41%, HCL Tech. down by 2.09% and Bajaj Auto down by 1.68% were the top losers.

Meanwhile, expressing hopes on growth of economy, Finance Secretary Subhash Chandra Garg has said that declining global oil prices, stable rupee and falling interest rate are sure signs of high growth in coming months following the government's data showed that India's economy slowed down in the fourth quarter as well as in full fiscal year 2018-19.

Garg said 'Turn around in demand and financing conditions beginning well. PMI manufacturing is at 52.7. Crude is moving towards 60 dollars. Govt bond yield has gone below 7%. Spread for NBFCs/HFCs over Govt bond is narrowing. Rupee is firmly below 70. Sure signs of coming high growth.' Earlier, he had said slowdown would continue in the first quarter of this fiscal. However, he had expressed hope that growth will pick up from the second quarter of the current financial year.

Besides, India's growth rate has declined to 5-year low of 5.8% in in Q4FY19 and the country lost the fastest-growing large economy status, trailing China's growth (6.4%) for the first time in nearly two years. The full-year GDP growth, too, slumped to a five-year low of 6.8% in FY19.

The CNX Nifty ended at 12033.05, down by 55.50 points or 0.46% after trading in a range of 12005.85 and 12095.20. There were 17 stocks advancing against 33 stocks declining on the index.

The top gainers on Nifty were Yes Bank up by 2.68%, Bharti Infratel up by 2.05%, Axis Bank up by 1.51%, NTPC up by 1.43% and Vedanta up by 1.07%.

On the flip side, Zee Entertainment down by 3.85%, Hero MotoCorp down by 2.85%, Asian Paints down by 2.55%, Indian Oil Corp. down by 2.50% and TCS down by 2.43% were the top losers.

European markets were trading in green; UK's FTSE 100 increased 12.07 points or 0.17% to 7,196.87, France's CAC rose 5.50 points or 0.1% to 5,246.96 and Germany's DAX was up by 104.68 points or 0.89% to 11,897.49.

Asian markets ended mostly lower on Tuesday in cautious trade as worries about rising trade tensions and impact on global economic growth sapped risk appetite. Tech stocks in Asia followed their US counterparts lower as news of an antitrust probe into big tech companies stoked concerns about the sector. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said that interest rates may have to be cut soon because of low inflation and the trade war's threat to the economy. Some forecasters now expect as many as two rate cuts by the end of the year. Seoul shares ended lower as weak GDP data and rising trade tensions dented investor sentiment. Meanwhile, Japanese shares closed flat with a negative bias in choppy trade amid worries about global economic growth and on a stronger safe-haven yen. The Indonesia market is closed all week in observance of Eid-ul-Fitr.

urn:contentItem:5XS8-YB41-F021-60BK-00000-00Pound continues to weaken as traders weigh up no-deal risk2019-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:24Pound continues to weaken as traders weigh up no-deal riskBy LaToya Harding, (now) and Louis Ashworth, (earlier)

The pound continued to wind down after its sharp spike last Thursday night and sharp fall on Tuesday, easing pressure on the FTSE 100, many constituents of which favour a weak sterling.That relief allowed the blue-chip FTSE 100 to outperform its continental peers, despite clocking up only moderate gains during the session.Other top stories today:

UK consumer price inflation stays at three-year low, but costs for older Britons rise

Bet365 chief Denise Coates retains crown as Britain's best-paid boss with huge payday

Pearson boss John Fallon to step down after six years

Staffline issues warning on performance and discloses accounting error

NMC Health hits back at short-seller report

FiatChrysler and Peugeot-owner PSA Groupe agree terms of merger

Ambrose Evans-Pritchard: Global rebound could help Trump back to the White House despite systemic risks

5:40PMMarket wrap:London's markets settled a little after several days of post-election volatility.The FTSE 250 - which has been seen as a bellwether for Brexit sentiment through the three and a half years since Britain voted to leave the EU - was flat during the day, but remains solidly higher than where it stood before the election.The index hit an all-time high on Monday.Thanks again for following along today, Louis Ashworth will be back in the morning.What to look forward to tomorrow:News flows will continue to be thin tomorrow , with fewer companies reporting because of the time of year. There are no major UK companies reporting.Economics: Retail sales, BoE monetary policy committee (UK); current account (US)   5:25PMSterling still downThe pound is still down against the dollar and the euro, trading 0.37pc lower against the dollar at $1.3079 and 0.06pc down against the euro at (EURO)1.1766.The currencyhas taken another knock on the back of fears surrounding a no-deal Brexit."Traders have traditionally been rattled by the prospect of the UK leaving the EU a deal in place, but that possibility might not be for one year. The negative move in sterling is partially driven by profit taking too as the pound has rallied against the US dollar since early September," says David Madden of CMC Markets.   5:16PMWhirlpool just the latest company sent into a spin by product recallsExploding glass, ice cream cones containing painkillers and batteries in chocolate Easter bunnies are among the disasters that have forced businesses to recall millions of products in recent years.Product recalls are the most severe level of safety warning issued by manufacturers and can have a catastrophic impact on not just on a company's bottom line-but can also decimate their reputation among customers. Earlier this year Fisher-Price recalled almost 5m Rock 'n Play infant sleepers in the US after more than 30 babies rolled over in them and died. The firm's owner, toy giant Mattel, was forced to set aside $27m to cover the cost of the recall and also faced legal action over claims that its advertising for the Rock 'n Play devices misled customers.   Read Hannah Uttley's report to find out more   4:57PMEuropean markets closeStocks in London have closed for the day, with the FTSE 100 closing 021pc higher to 7,540.75 and the FTSE 250 falling 0.12pc to 21,663.13,The pound is still suffering from Brexit worries,which pushed international companies higher.Pharmaceutical firm Hikma jumped 4pc and global equipment rental company climbed Ashtead 3pc .On the opposite end of the scale, UK housebuilders were among the biggest fallers with Berkeley and Persimmon both down 2pc.European Closing Prices:   #FTSE 7540.75 +0.21%   #DAX 13222.16-0.49%   #CAC 5959.6-0.15%   #AEX 606.04-0.03%   #MIB 23628.87-0.01%   #IBEX 9621.8 +0.06%   #STOXX 3742.93-0.06%- IGSquawk (@IGSquawk)   December 18, 2019   4:41PMAnalysis: $50bn Fiat-Peugeot deal underlines the pressure on carmakers from an electric future"The $50bn merger of PSA Group and FiatChrysler is just the latest example of how the car industry is facing up to a worrying future," my colleague Alan Tovey writes. Although electric vehicles herald a cleaner world, the massive upheaval that developing and building these environmentally friendly cars also entails costs that are straining balance sheets. Other technology, such as self-driving systems, just piles on the pressure.All this comes against a backdrop of a slowing global economy and easing sales, with some thinking that the world may have already hit "peak car", with the growth of car sharing and autonomous vehicles only likely to lessen the necessity to actually own a vehicle.   Read his full analysis here   4:33PMGood afternoonWe'll be taking a look at how markets in Europe closed very shortly.There was a sense of weariness to the markets this Wednesday, caught between the election-slash-trade deal overstimulation of the last few sessions, and the awareness that the end of the year draws ever closer, says Connor Campbell at SpreadEx. He adds:"Capturing the mood, the Dow Jones barely moved after the bell. Sat a big yawn and stretch away from 28300, the US index remains in the vicinity of its all-time highs without showing much appetite for another gold medal sprint."The CAC was similarly laconic, adding a handful of points. The DAX, on the other hand, shed 0.4pc, even though the German Ifo business climate reading beat expectations."The day's only real major index-winner was the FTSE, which knocked on the door of 7550 - a level last properly seen at the end of July - following a 25 point increase."   4:24PMHandoverDarkness has firmly descended, and I must prepared my market report. Luckily, my colleague LaToya Harding is close at hand to guide you through the long tunnel of business news. I'll be back tomorrow!   4:15PMSo, what does 'Workington Man' want from the Tories?'Workington Man', identified by a think-tank early in the general election campaign as the type of voter the Tories needed to win from Labour, became a much-derided caricature - but the region was one of many that swung behind the Conservatives in the final count. My colleague Lizzy Burden went to speak to the real people of Workington, and find out what they want from the UK's newly-invigorated Conservative Government. She writes:With the political contest won, the Government's attention is now turning to the economic demands of this former steel-making coastal town, which, like many other constituencies across the North and Midlands,   lent the Prime Minister its votesdespite being a Labour heartland for decades.

:What 'Workington Man' wants from Boris Johnson's resurgent Tories

   3:41PMAJ Bell founder sells part of stake for £23mThe founder of investment platform AJ Bell insisted he remains committed to the business after selling £23m worth of shares to raise "a few quid to go and play with".My colleague Michael O'Dwyer reports:Andy Bell, chief executive of the firm he co-founded in 1995, reduced his stake from 25pc to 24pc and will remain the company's largest shareholder. Shares in AJ Bell have more than doubled in value since the fund shop floated on the London Stock Exchange in December 2018. The surge means Mr Bell's remaining stake is worth about £415m. One industry analyst described the shares' current valuation as "stratospheric". None of the five analysts covering the firm's stock has a buy recommendation, according to Bloomberg data, indicating a reluctance to bet on further price rises.

: Andy Bell sells £23m stake in stockbroker he founded at 'stratospheric' price after float success

   3:35PMFTSE 250 holds up despite post-election wobblesThe FTSE 250 - seen as a bellwether for Brexit - is down only slightly today. The mid-cap index is still pretty perky despite some market nerves about Boris Johnson's approach to negotiations with the EU, that have knocked the pound. Here's how it has moved in recent days.   3:08PMFrasers Group slips slightly after Monday's surgeSports Direct The group formerly known as Sports Direct's shares are slipping today. Frasers Group is losing some of the ground it gained after surging on Monday.

: Mike Ashley mulls £100m bonus bonanza for staff as Sports Direct shares soar'I'm not a panto villain': Mike Ashley's mask slips with outburst at Sports Direct investor summit

   2:59PMUniversity of York gets £160m, 45-year loan to expand student accommodationThe Pension Insurance Corporation, which insures defined benefit pension funds, has struck a £160m investment deal with the University of York, to fund the Russell Group institution's plans to build 1,500 new rooms.The funds will be used to construct: "around 1,500 high-quality en-suite rooms for students in a facility which will also provide student study spaces, exhibition spaces, cafes and a number of university departments".PIC's Florence Carasse said:We are delighted to have agreed this deal with the University of York, one of the top UK universities, which has demonstrated strong demand historically and will benefit from the expansion of its Campus East, to further improve student satisfaction.   2:46PMImpeachment is unlikely to rattle marketsIt may be too early to speak on this front, but the Donald Trump impeachment vote set to take place in the US Congress later today is unlikely to move markets particularly.Currently, the issue has been so driven along party lines that any attempt to remove the President would likely be batted down in the Republican-held Senate.

Will Donald Trump be impeached? Latest news from the inquiry, explained Oliver Wiseman: Why Donald Trump's inevitable impeachment will fail to live up to the hype

   2:42PMWall Street advancesOver on Wall Street, markets have opened higher despite nagging doubts about the US-China trade war.   2:26PMFull report: Google and Facebook face crackdown over adsMy colleague Matthew Field has a full report on the Competition & Markets Authority's crackdown on Google and Facebook. He writes:The Competition and Markets Authority on Wednesday released the initial findings of its   market studyinto digital advertising, launching the next stage of its review with a call for responses to potential remedies and a possible market investigation.The CMA is investigating the power of Google and Facebook over the UK digital advertising market as part of a probe launched in July. It found Google accounted for 90pc of all search advertising revenues in Britain last year worth about £6bn, while Facebook had half of all display adverts worth some £2bn.The watchdog said Google and Facebook had both achieved "strategic market status", potentially harming consumer choice, damaging publishers and newspapers and hampering technical innovation.

: Google's advertising stranglehold threatened by big tech crackdown

   2:21PMBlackstone buys warehouse-owner Hansteen for £500mBlackstone has snapped up Hansteen, the London-listed real estate investment trust, in a £500m deal, my colleague Rachel Millard reports. She writes:The US private equity giant said it believed Hansteen's portfolio of warehouses could be put to good use by its logistics real estate company Mileway. It is hoped the deal could be the start of   a surge of foreign private equity investmentinto UK real estate following the resounding Conservative victory in the general election, which removed political uncertainty stalling the sector. Blackstone is one of the world's largest real estate investors, managing about $157bn of investors' funds.

: Blackstone snaps up warehouse owner Hansteen in £500m deal

   2:16PMTanks for that: BAE Systems wins $249m US Army contractBAE Systems has been awarded a $249m contract by the US Army to build 60 new M109A7 howitzers and their accompanying carrier vehicles.For any military tech wonks reading:The vehicle design includes a new chassis, engine, transmission, suspension, steering system, a new high voltage architecture and improved survivability, while the vehicle's cannon remains the same as that of an M109A6 Paladin.The award is the extension of a contract first won by Britain's BAE in 2017, and will bring the total number of sets - carrier and howitzer - supplied to 156.BAE's Jeremy Tondreault said:The M109A7 positions the Army to execute its current mission with confidence and support its future needs and requirements as long range precision fires evolve.   2:05PMMoney round-upHere are some of the day's top stories from the Telegraph Money team:

Marcus axes bonus on its once market-leading savings account'I want to retire at 58 on £45k a year. Is £1.4m enough?'Mike Warburton: Tax hacks: the ultimate (painless) guide to filling out your 2018-19 tax return

   1:52PMAudit sector set for sweeping reformsThe audit sector is set for sweeping changes after an independent review recommended a shake-up to restore confidence following a series of company collapses. My colleague Michael O'Dwyer reports:City grandee Sir Donald Brydon, who was hired by the Government to carry out a review of the sector, has proposed splitting the audit and accountancy professions and introducing new responsibilities for company directors to help stamp out fraud. The report called for the purpose of the audit profession to be redefined to boost confidence in companies, directors and the information they publish.This would mark a change from a narrower focus on companies' financial statements, towards a broader consideration of the public interest. The review found that auditors should be responsible for rooting out fraud in companies. David Dunckley, the boss of Patisserie Valerie's auditor Grant Thornton, triggered a backlash in January when he told MPs that his firm was   "not set up to look for fraud".

: Sweeping reforms to lift 'cloud' over audit sector

   12:57PMFull report: Inflation hits retired Britons hardestMy colleague Tim Wallace has a full report on this morning's inflation figures. He writes:Living costs are rising faster for retired Britons than for the wider population, as a record gap in inflation rates opens up a new divide between people of different ages.Prices rose by 1.8pc for those aged over 65 in the 12 months to September, but by 1.6pc for working-aged families.The gap was driven by the rising cost of package holidays-disproportionately bought by older travellers-compared with lower transport costs, which aided those heading to work every day. Toys and games are also getting cheaper, benefitting younger households, which are more likely than grandparents to purchase video games.Inflation rates vary for everyone because each person spends their money on different items and in different quantities, but the Office for National Statistics seeks to calculate an overall rate for average households.

: Pricey cruises help drive up cost of living for pensioners

   12:45PMWorld's largest crane completes first operation at Hinkley Point COvernight, Hinkley Point C engineers managed to complete the first big lift by 'Big Carl', the world's largest crane.The 250m tall crane lifted a 170 tonne prefabricated part of the reactor's steel containment liner into place at 4.30am, taking advantage of a small weather window.The site's managing director Stuart Crooks said:The first big lift is another impressive achievement and I want to thank the teams who've worked so hard to make this possible. Here are some pictures from the lift:   12:39PMFCA fines Hall and Hanley over PPI breachesYesterday, we reported that the City watchdog hadissued its first fine against a claims management company for misconduct during the rush to claim money from banks over PPI mis-selling,Today, we have a second: the Financial Conduct Authority had charged Hall and Hanley Limited £91,000 over "data breaches and unauthorised copying of client signatures" in relation to PPI claims.The FCA said it had found:[H&H] had breached rules requiring CMCs to take all reasonable steps to ensure that any referrals, leads or data purchased from third parties had been obtained in accordance with applicable laws. Marketing text messages concerning PPI claims were sent to consumers' mobile telephone numbers, without H&H having taken sufficient steps to check that affected consumers had consented to receiving such messages.A tribunal concluded the group had acted negligently.Mark Steward, the regulator's director of enforcement, said:The failure by Hall and Hanley to take previous advice and warnings from the former claims management regulator and the firm's repeated use of consumer data and customer signatures without their consent are clear examples of a firm falling short of the standards we expect.The decision by the Tribunal to uphold the findings of the CMR is another important message to industry that firms must conduct all business with integrity and due care, skill, and diligence.   12:31PMJLR rescues off-road brand BowlerJaguar Land Rover has bought niche car manufacturer Bowler out of administration.My colleague Alan Tovey reports:Founded in 1985, Bowler hand-built small numbers of vehicles for rallies and offroad racing, turning Land Rovers into high-performance all-terrain vehicles.The company had struggled for the past few years. It collapsed into administration earlier this week, with JLR's special vehicle operations (SVO) arm buying the business for an undisclosed amount, saving the jobs of Bowler's 26 permanent staff.

: JaguarLand Rover rescues off-road racer Bowler out of administration

   11:54AMBang & Olufsen issues fourth profit warning in a yearFour profit warnings in a year seems a little bit more than unfortunate, but that's the situation Danish high-end TV and audio company Bang & Olufsen finds itself in, my colleague Chris Johnston reports.He writes:B&O said on Wednesday that sales last month were considerably lower than expected, wiping as much as 25pc off its shares in Copenhagen. "All alarm bells are ringing, and who can have the confidence that there won't be a fifth, or maybe even a sixth profit warning," says Per Hansen at Nordnet in Copenhagen. "It ought to be clear that B&O's future is not as an independent company."Sales this year will fall as much as 18pc, compared with a previous forecast for an expansion.It's unlikely to be a merry Christmas for Kristian Tear, a former Blackberry chief operating officer who joined as chief executive in October. He says B&O's strategic direction remains unchanged, but that "fundamental change of the sales and marketing efforts is required".Mr Tear will be hoping Santa can fit a few Beolab 90 speakers in his sack this year -though at 136kg and about £60,000 that could be wishful thinking.   11:48AMWatchdog says there is 'strong argument' for regulation of digital giantsThe Competition & Markets Authority has said there is a "strong argument" for the development of a new regulatory regime to rein digital giants Google and Facebook.In an update to its ongoing investigation into the digital advertising sector, the regulator said "'Big' is not necessarily 'bad'", but warned:A lack of real competition to Google and Facebook could mean people are already missing out on the next great new idea from a potential rival. It could also be resulting in a lack of proper choice for consumers and higher prices for advertisers that can mean cost rises for goods and services such as flights, electronics and insurance bought online.The market position of Google and Facebook may potentially be undermining the ability of newspapers and other publishers to produce valuable content as their share of revenues is squeezed by large platforms.It said it was concerned about a lack of transparency in how the Silicon Valley companies operate, and low levels of public understanding around how data is used online. The watchdog added:At this stage, the CMA agrees with Professor Furman and his colleagues who carried out a wide-ranging review of digital markets earlier this year, that there is a strong argument for the development of a new regulatory regime. This could include rules governing the behaviour of online platforms and giving people greater control over their own data.It said proposals that could potentially work included:

Measures to open up the search market including potentially stopping Google from being the default search engine on many devicesRequiring Facebook to "connect more seamlessly" with other social networking websitesIntroducing measures to address conflicts of interest and a lack of transparency in digital advertisingAllowing people to turn off all personalised advertising

The CMA will issue its full report next year.   11:31AMBank of England to test firms over climate-change readinessThe Bank of England is to become the first central bank to test how well banks and insurers can weather the threat of economic shocks and market turmoil inspired by climate change.My colleague Tom Rees reports:Firms will be stress-tested against three different climate change scenarios over a 30-year horizon but they will not be named and shamed, its discussion paper revealed.Under its plans, companies will submit the risks they face and the actions they expect to take in response to the threat. Threadneedle Street will then reveal the systemic threats facing the UK's financial industry in 2021.Governor Mark Carney warned on Wednesday that climate change will affect the "value of virtually every financial asset", calling the tests a "pioneering exercise".

: Bank of England to test financial firms over climate change threat

   11:24AMPound pattern points to further falls To make matters worse for the pound, Bloomberg notes that the currency has achieved an   'evening star' patternin its movements, which suggests further falls are likely. It reports:Euphoria over Prime Minister Boris Johnson's landslide win sent it to the highest close since March on Monday. A day later, it suffered its worst sell-off in more than a year after he announced plans to set a Brexit deadline of December 2020. It lost as much as 0.4pc against the dollar on Wednesday.To make matters worse for cable, it completed a technical pattern that suggests the rout probably isn't a blip. The so-called Evening Star candle pattern, which forms over three days and uses the currency's intraday highs and lows to show a sudden shift in sentiment, is sending early warning signals.The pattern can be made out on the right-hand side of the diagram below (if you are using a mobile, this may not be possible to see).   10:55AMPersimmon continues to slideShares in Persimmon are falling for a second consecutive day, after the housebuilder revealed limitations in a ratings system relied on by millions of home-buyers.

Ratings relied on by millions of homeowners under fire in damning Persimmon review

​My colleague Rachel Millard has taken a deep-dive look at where things went wrong for the company. She writes:The company has been under fire for years over its shoddy workmanship - even as it paid out a bonus of £75m to former chief executive Jeff Fairburn. On Tuesday, it published the   damning findings of an independent review and apologised to customers, trying to draw a line under the problems which have cast a shadow over the industry and given huge ammunition to critics of corporate excess and wealth inequality.

: 'Crooks, cowboys and con-artists': How Persimmon went from star housebuilder to corporate pariah

   10:36AM...but it might not happen until next summerProbabilities polled by Bloomberg suggest a cut to rates is most likely to land next summer. Nobody is expecting a hike anytime in 2020.   10:26AMAnalysts lean towards a 2020 cutPolling by Bloomberg suggests analysts think it is very unlikely that the Bank of England - which has been keeping cool and calm on rates in recent meetings - will make any kind of move tomorrow. In fact, the currently-implied probability of rates being held is 99pc.Even just looking at the next meeting in January suggests a rise in expectations of a rate cut.   10:12AMHouse price growth hits seven-year low UK house price growth during the year to October was the worst since September 2012, with an average increase of just 0.7pc.The average house price during the month was £233,000.The lowest growth rate was in London, where prices fell 1.6pc year-on-year. The ONS said:While house prices in London continued to fall over the year, the area remains the most expensive place to purchase a property, at an average of £472,000.   10:02AMReaction: MPC may hold ratesWith those inflation figures in, attention will swing to the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee meeting tomorrow.Capital Economics' Ruth Gregory writes:November's inflation figures support our view that the MPC will sit tight at its meeting tomorrow and keep interest rates on hold throughout 2020. After all, at 1.5pc, the unchanged rate of inflation was a little above the projection made by the Bank of England in November and the consensus forecast of 1.4pc...Admittedly, the figures confirmed that price pressures at the start of the production process remain very weak. The annual rate of input price inflation remained close to October's three-and-a-half year low. And output price inflation slipped further from 0.8pc to 0.5pc in November. As a result, with inflation well below target, little sign of underlying price pressures and GDP growth running below trend, an interest rate cut on Thursday shouldn't be completely ruled out.Even so, coupled with yesterday's robust labour market figures the pressure on the MPC to cut interest rates at its meeting tomorrow appears to have eased somewhat. We continue to expect the MPC to keep rates on hold at 0.75pc on Thursday and for some time to come.Here's how the Bank's base rate currently stands:   9:51AMUK inflation stays at three-year lowConsumer price inflation in the UK has stayed at its lowest rate since 2016, which is likely to compound calls for an interest rate cut from the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee when it meets tomorrow.The overall CPI inflation rate was 1.5pc (against expectations of a 1.4pc rise), with the core measure - which excludes volatile elements such as fuel - at 1.7pc.The ONS said the largest contribution to higher prices came from "housing, water, electricity, gas and other fuels", with recreation and culture prices also rising.There was also a large contribution from the food and non-alcoholic beverages section, in which "boxes and cartons of chocolates, and chocolate covered ice cream bars drove the upward movement".The figure remains below the Bank's target inflation rate of 2pc.   9:36AMBoom day for windfarms means some drivers paid to charge their carsMy colleague Ed Clowes reports:Have you ever dreamt of being paid to use electricity, rather than the other way around?Well, electric vehicle owners across the country were lucky enough to discover what this felt like on December 8, when they were actually paid to charge their cars thanks to the blustery weather conditions.High winds caused excess electricity on the grid, and to use it up, electrical vehicle owners on an Octopus tariff and using Ohme chargers were notified of the opportunity to be paid to juice their cars.The UK's wind farms generated a record amount of electricity that day, accounting for 45pc of the country's energy.   9:27AMGerman business sentiment improveBusiness expectations in Germany have continued to improve, according to the latest survey data from the Ifo Institute.A climb in sentiment indicators across the board suggests manufacturers are starting to see the light at the end of the tunnel after a yearlong downturn. It follows purchasing managers' index this Monday which showed an unexpected worsening in factory activity at the end of the year.   9:06AMHere's how the pound is moving...Sterling is continuing to slip after its fairly sharp drop yesterday:   9:01AMEurope mixedStock indices across the continent are pretty mixed this morning, with the FTSE 100 being given a slight upwards tip by a weakened pound (which reduces pressure on internationally-exposed stocks). CMC Markets' Michael Hewson said:Yesterday's modest pullback in European markets wasn't enough to prevent US markets from making new record highs last night, nonetheless as we head towards the middle of the last full trading week of 2019, investors appear to be adopting a much more safety first approach, as the euphoria of a US, China détente and a new Conservative majority government quickly fade.   8:37AMCentamin says efforts to engage with Endeavour have hit a stalemateLondon-listed gold miner Centamin said efforts to engage with prospective buyer Endeavour, have hit a stalemate.The group said it could not assess the takeover properly without further information from Canada-based Endeavour, which has refused to share information unless Centamin agrees to a December 31 decision deadline.Earlier this week, the groups said a meeting had occurred between their bosses in an attempt to strike out terms for a potential deal.

: Gold miners Centamin and Endeavour meet to discuss merger

Centamin said:The Centamin board is disappointed that despite its efforts at constructive engagement, Endeavour has repeatedly refused to engage in a proper manner. The unsolicited approach from Endeavour has created an intense period of uncertainty for all of the company's stakeholders. Therefore, the board of Centamin believes that Endeavour should, without further delay, enter into substantive reciprocal due diligence.   8:19AMStaffline plunges after performance warning and accounting errorsShares in recruitment company Staffline have plunged by a third today after the group warned on its trading performance and said it had found accounting errors in its 2018 results.The group said its adjusted operating profit for the fourth quarter would be in the region of £10m-£12m, down from previously estimates of £20m. It said:During November, customer demand was down approximately 16pc from the prior year which the board believes reflects high levels of consumer uncertainty across the UK. Whilst trading in December has improved, trading performance for the month is also anticipated to be below the board's expectationsIt said a "rigorous internal review" had discovered problems with its 2018 accounts that led it to overstate its profits by around £4m. The group said: "These errors primarily relate to costs which were not correctly booked".The group also said it had replaced chief financial officer Mike Watts, who left the group with immediate effect. His role will be taken up on an interim basis by Daniel Quint.   8:13AMBet365's Coates retains title as UK's highest-paid bossBet365 boss Denise Coates has bagged a £320m payday, catapulting her up Britain's rich list and maintaining her position as the country's best-paid executive.My colleague Oliver Gill reports:The gambling chief executive, who founded Bet365 in a Portakabin overlooking her dad's original Stoke-on-Trent betting shop, is believed to have paid herself a £277m salary while taking home a 50pc share of the company's £92.5m dividend payout.Bet365, fiercely secretive and one of the world's biggest online gambling companies, revealed record sales of almost £3bn in accounts published on Wednesday.   Last year the gaming boss took home £220m in salary and £45m in dividends.

: Bet365 chief Denise Coates retains crown as Britain's best paid boss with huge payday

   8:08AMPearson shares riseShares in education firm Pearson have risen about 5pc this morning, with investors apparently welcoming the exit of boss John Fallon and its decision to shed the last of its stake in Penguin Random House.   8:06AMFinablr talks tough after being caught in NMC crossfirePayments firm Finablr has issued a statement following a nearly 11pc share price fall yesterday, saying there was "no financial or operational reason" for the fall.The FTSE 250 group was hit by the fallout from Muddy Waters' short attack on NMC Health. Both firms were founded and are chaired by Indian businessman BR Shetty.Finablr said it:[R]emains on track to achieve the guidance that it set out at its IPO, which was reaffirmed in its trading update on 11 November 2019.   7:58AMNMC Health says it will review Muddy Waters reportHospital operator NMC Health has said it will review the allegations made in a short-seller claimed it had understated its debts. The company's share price slump yesterday after the report was released. My colleague Hannah Uttley reported yesterday:Shares plunged 32pc to £17.47 following an attack in which US short-seller Muddy Waters accused the FTSE 100 company of understating its debt by about $320m (£242m).Muddy Waters said NMC had failed to properly report leases in its 2018 accounts associated with British hospital operator Aspen Healthcare, which it bought for £10m last year.

: NMC Health shares plunge after short-seller takes aim

Responding today, NMC said:NMC understands its regulatory disclosure obligations and has nothing to add to disclosures already made. It has already responded to many of the allegations made in the report over the past 12 months...NMC will review the assertions, insinuations and accusations made in the report, which appear principally unfounded, baseless and misleading, containing many errors of fact, and will respond in detail in due course.The company said it had also puts plans in place to launch its previously-announced $200m share buyback scheme.   7:51AMPearson boss to step downPearson has announced its chief executive John Fallon will leave the company next year after more than six years in the role. My colleague Simon Foy reports:The troubled education publisher said Mr Fallon will only depart once a successor has been appointed in order to ensure an orderly transition. Pearson's chairman Sidney Taurel, who will lead the succession process, said: "In some very challenging markets, John has worked tirelessly leading Pearson through a period of significant change and led its transformation from a media conglomerate to a single focused learning company."It comes after a torrid year for the company in which it has lost a third of its value, making it the worst-performing media stock of 2019, as it struggles to deal with increasing competition and changing education practices. The company   warned on profits in September. Separately, the FTSE 100 company said it has agreed to sell its remaining 25pc stake in Penguin Random House to Bertelsmann for $675m (£530m) in an attempt to raise cash.

: Pearson boss John Fallon to step down after six years

   7:43AMWhat happened overnightRecord highs on Wall Street were not echoed in the Asian markets this morning. The Nikkei 225 erased earlier gains to inch down 0.3pc to 24,000.36 in morning trading.Australia's S&P/ASX 200 gained 0.2pc to 6,862.50. South Korea's Kospi was little changed, slipping down to 2,193.73. Hong Kong's Hang Seng edged up nearly 0.3pc to 27,916.48. while the Shanghai Composite added 0.3pc to 3,032.10.   7:35AMCar giants to mergeFiat Chrysler and Peugeot-owner PSA Groupe have signed binding merger terms to create the world's fourth-biggest car group by sales, Alan Tovey writes.Following board meetings on Tuesday, the companies confirmed details of the 50:50 tie-up that will result in a business that sells 8.7m vehicles annually, generating revenues of almost (EURO)170bn (£144bn).Joining forces is expected to generate annual savings of (EURO)3.7bn a year. About 40pc of the synergies are set to come sharing vehicle platforms, with more than two thirds of all cars produced coming on just two basic platforms.

Read our report here

7:34AM Agenda: Pound shaken

The FTSE 100 just about managed to close in positive territory yesterday, cushioned by a falling pound. It edged up 0.08pc while the domestically focused FTSE 250 tumbled 1.05pc.

Sterling tumbled during the session on the news that Boris Johnson plans to enshrine the Brexit deadline in law, increasing concerns about the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.

5 things to start your day

1) Royal Dutch Shell has revealed that it paid no corporate income tax in the UK in 2018despite raking in $731m (£557m) of pre-tax profit on revenues of $108bn in the country. The new report is the first time the oil and gas titan has released public details of the corporate income tax paid in countries and locations across all its businesses.

2) City giants predict investors will pile into UK stocks in 2020 but warn of global 'new reality': Sheer relief of the Brexit deadlock being broken could trigger a rapid jump of London's stock market as investors look beyond our departure from the European Union, said Richard Buxton, head of UK equities at Merian Global Investors.

3) The PM who saw off Labour now needs labour: The cost of builders is rising as a shortage of workers bites-but Boris Johnson will need them more than ever as he tries to rebuild with true-blue bricks Labour's "red wall" in the Midlands and North.

4) The accounting watchdog has cracked down on auditors from providing consulting and recruitment services to clients whose books they review in a bid to bolster independenceand stamp out conflicts of interest.

5)'Boris boom' to lift Northern housebuilders, says Peel Hunt: This investment bonanza is expected to boost property markets-offering the potential for investors to make a bumper profit.

Coming up today

No major UK companies reporting.

Economics: Consumer and producer prices (UK); Ifo business climate (Germany)

value.Title: Pound hits two-year lows on no-deal chatter as merger bonanza lifts FTSE

The proposed deal puts the Blackstone-backed consortium that owns Refinitiv in a position of potential power , something the City might not welcome with open arms.   Sources have also told Reuters the tie-up would face substantial scrutiny from competition regulators.  It reports: Antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States are expected to start an in-depth review which may last up to 18 months, the sources said. In the European Union, ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WP0-XK81-JCJY-G19X-00000-00Pound hits two-year lows on no-deal chatter as merger bonanza lifts FTSE2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:17Pound hits two-year lows on no-deal chatter as merger bonanza lifts FTSEBy Louis Ashworth, Markets Reporter

Sterling falls to two-year lows as deal talk lifts FTSE

London Stock Exchange Group aims for £42 billion tie-up with data firm Refinitiv

Just Eat leaps 24pc on talk of £9bn merger with Dutch rival Takeaway.com

Friday night chaos stings Sports Direct shares

 James Titcomb:  The trade war Silicon Valley should be worried about isn't between the US and China

'No one is ready for no deal' Brexit in industry, government or the EU, CBI warns

2:31PM Trump attacks Fed over QE and rates

Over in the White House, US President Donald Trump is interspersing his current tweet war with the entire city of Baltimore with some opinions onone of his favourite topics: the Federal Reserve.

Outside of his dubious claims about the foundation of the EU and coining of the phrase "easy pickens", the President of the United States appears to mainly be continuing his call for a bigger rate cut when the Fed meets later this week. They are currently expected to reduce interest rates by 0.25 percentage points.

The Fed "raised" way too early and way too much. Their quantitative tightening was another big mistake. While our Country is doing very well, the potential wealth creation that was missed, especially when measured against our debt, is staggering. We are competing with other.....- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1155829888701673472?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019
....countries that know how to play the game against the U.S. That's actually why the E.U. was formed....and for China, until now, the U.S. has been "easy pickens." The Fed has made all of the wrong moves. A small rate cut is not enough, but we will win anyway!- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1155829890903617536?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019
2:21PM Just Eat activist welcomes merger plan

Cat Rock Capital, the US-based activist that seems to have got exactly what it wanted from the proposed Just Eat/Takeaway.com tie-up, has (unsurprisingly) welcomed the merger.

Boss Alex Captain, who has led its criticism of Just Eat's leadership, says:

We would like to commend Chairman Mike Evans and the Board for taking clear and decisive action to realize Just Eat's great potential, particularly in a structure that allows long-term shareholders to participate meaningfully in future value creation.

The proposed transaction is excellent news for Just Eat shareholders. The combined company would be an exceptionally high-quality business with formidable market positions in major countries, fantastic growth prospects, and world-class management.

We support the board's work in evaluating and consummating a transaction that maximizes long-term shareholder value over the coming weeks.

2:18PM FTSE rise passes 2pc as pounds hits fresh lows

The trend of the day looks set to continue, with strong climbers and a weak pound sending the FTSE 100 up around 2pc. Sterling has now dropped as low as $1.2239, its biggest one-day loss since March - if it falls much further, it could pass its 16th January 2017 low ($1.2068) to hit levels not seen since the 1980s.

Here's a historic visualisation of that FTSE/sterling relationship...

...or, more simply... 

I did a 'splainer https://t.co/qsm8hPtu7Xpic.twitter.com/qsm8hPtu7X - Lorcan Roche Kelly (@LorcanRK)   https://twitter.com/LorcanRK/status/783266032395882496?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwOctober 4, 2016

... although perhaps it is particularly unusual for such a severe drop in the pound's value to land at the same time as £50bn of mergers.

1:35PM Pfizer unites EpiPens and Viagra in Mylan tie-up

Pharma giant Pfizer is set to combine its Upjohn unit, which makes Viagra, with Mylan, the EpiPen maker, as part of an all-share deal that will have a major impact on the industry.

The deal, after which Prizer shareholders would own 57pc of the combined company and Mylan shareholders 43pc, is likely to majorly shake-up the ex-patent drugs industry. The new company formed will be publicly traded and have sales of $19bn to $20bn next year, the companies said.

The deal allows Pfizer to shed its blockbusters of years past in order to streamline its growth-generating operations, while offering a management change and new revenue streams for Mylan.

1:17PM Round-up: Unions pledge to fight Vauxhall pull-out, Sports Direct gets a kicking

Here are our full reports on two of the day's biggest stories, from Laura Onita and Michael O'Dwyer:

Unions vow to fight 'tooth and nail' to save Vauxhall jobs at Ellesmere Port : Unions representing Vauxhall workers at Ellesmere Port have warned they will fight "tooth and nail" to protect jobs at the plant after the boss of the car maker's parent company said production would be pulled from the UK in the event of a bad Brexit deal.

Sports Direct shares plunge after results farrago : Investors in Mike Ashley's Sports Direct swiftly dumped shares after revelations of an unpaid £600m tax bill last week during the retailer's shambolic financial results. 

1:09PM Pound falls under $1.23

Sterling has slipped beneath the symbolic marker of $1.23, a low not seen since the middle of March 2017. It looks like American traders are raising pressure on the pound as markets open there.

Markets Hub - US Dollar   12:53PM Meanwhile, just days after Britain basked in 38 degree heat...

...Selfridges has launched its in-house Christmas store! In this climate of economic doubt and gathering clouds over global trade, 149 days early seems like the perfect time to get shopping.

The department store is running its festive fare under the title 'Future Fantasy', which to be fair is probably all Christmas can possible feel like given we're in July. It says:

Boldly going into a futuristic vision of Christmas for its 2019's theme - Future Fantasy - Selfridges rethinks traditional, beloved festive stories and re-tells tales as old as time, but through a modern lens.

The shop's theme will include "neon hues that contrast with silvers and icy blues" and "introduce a collection of bespoke baubles representative of the brand itself ".

Selfridges' Eleanor Gregory, says: "We have so many customers visiting from all over the world, eager to snap up festive decorations and souvenirs on their London summer holidays which they can't buy at home."

Presumably the current value of the pound means you'll could soon see tourists with bags full of baubles and crackers on the Piccadilly line.

12:25PM Sterling hits fresh day lows

The pound hit fresh daily lows against the dollar a few minutes ago, hitting $1.2305. 

It looks like traders aren't big fans of new foreign secretary Dominic Raab's refusal to confirm he will visit European capitals .

12:20PM Analysis: Could Just Eat deal be start of food-delivery feeding frenzy?

Just Eat is surging on the FTSE, up over 30pc currently to reach highs it hasn't seen since last summer. 

A few months of activist pressure  is seemingly all it took for the food delivery firm to   capitulate, and it is now looking a merger with Takeaway.com that serves up big on the coverage front (the companies only clash in Switzerland), but offers less in the way of synergies.

Of the Just Eat board, only finance director Paul Scott Harrison seems set to keep his role, with a headquarters transfer to the Netherlands meaning the FTSE 100 company is basically switching heads.

That is, of course, if the deal goes ahead. There are other mid-level players in the good delivery sector who could give Just Eat the dynamism it is looking for: analysts have pointed to rival Delivery Hero as an example, while big tech funds might also be hungry for an opportunity. Olivetree analysts write:

There will likely be much focus on the concept that a third party might look to compete for Just Eat... For example, Naspers, which is in the middle of rationalising its own portfolio and will be cash-rich for acquisitions, said only recently that they see the food delivery space as incredibly attractive

The move could spark a wider shake-up in the food delivery sector, which Bloomberg Intelligence analysts estimate to be worth $100bn worldwide. Smaller rivals such as Uber Eats and Deliveroo have powerful private equity backers, but have shown less of an ability to turn a profit. Competition regulators are also keeping a close eye on the sector, having paused Amazon's Deliveroo investment as they probe the sector.

Food delivery - Restaurants signed up in the UK

There's an element of comparing apples and oranges to all this: Just Eat and Takeaway.com have traditionally acted as a a conduit between buyers and restaurants, meaning they can make a big margin on orders by charging a fee without taking on delivery duties.

Increasingly though, both have been shifting to more directly compete with Uber Eats and Deliveroo, which both provide their own riders. That's where the growth is, but no necessarily the profits. Food for thought.

11:51AM Market 'overestimates' Pearson risk

Education giant Pearson is among the top blue-chip risers today, up just over 2pc. 

That could be down to some positive figures from last week, which showed growth across its operations, and a note from Citi analysts this morning which said the stock was being unfairly underestimated. Citi writes:

Our contention is simply that the market overestimates the amount of structural risk within the name while underappreciating the group's relative cyclical and financial security.

The firm has been undertaken a large-scale pivot to digital learning in recent years, shedding previous assets such as the Financial Times, which it sold to Japanese media group Nikkei.

Markets Hub - Pearson PLC   11:43AM Revolut taps students and social stars for publicity

A fun story this morning from the Telegraph Tech desk's James Cook on fintech starlet Revolut.

James reports the firm is paying social media influencers and student union presidents to promote its products. He writes:

An email sent to customers earlier this month said that the company wants to recruit people who have "a confident tone, a loyal audience and an enthusiasm for better money services".

Revolut say promoters can earn up to (EURO)36 (£32) for each customer they bring to the digital bank.

You can read the full report here .

11:37AM Mirror and Express boss set to exit

Simon Fox, chief executive of British media conglomerate Reach, which publishes the Mirror and Express newspapers, is set to step down next month.

He's overseen a substantial share price rise at the company, formerly known as Trinity Mirror. Fox said:

There is never an ideal time to leave an organisation, but if there were, it would be now. The integration of the Express and Star has been successfully completed, digital growth is accelerating and our trading and cash position are strong.

You can read a full report here:

Daily Mirror and Express boss Simon Fox reaches end of the road after seven years

Markets Hub - Reach PLC   11:31AM Sterling worst performer among G10 currencies since Johnson entered No. 10

The pound is currently worth $1.2331, narrowly above the lows it reached at 10am, but still firmly in the doldrums.

Here's Sky News' Ed Conway:

In the five days since https://twitter.com/BorisJohnson?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw@BorisJohnson became Prime Minister the pound sterling has been the worst-performing major currency in the world   https://t.co/vBmR6Q1BHGpic.twitter.com/vBmR6Q1BHG - Ed Conway (@EdConwaySky)   https://twitter.com/EdConwaySky/status/1155780496225427456?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019

 And Philip Coggan of the Economist:

For those Britons holidaying in the US, the Boris tax is 22%, based on the pound's decline against the dollar- Philip Coggan (@econbartleby) https://twitter.com/econbartleby/status/1155782068435062784?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019
11:16AM Aston Martin shares stuck in reverse

Aston Martin shares are in the red again today (down 4.3pc), following a disastrous week in which it cut its order expectations for the year.

Now, Jefferies analysts Philippe Houchois and Himanshu Agarwal say the luxury car maker may make a call for new cash during its half-year results announcement on Wednesday. They write:

The critical issue when AML reports on Wednesday is whether new capital is required, what form this could take and who would provide it.

Markets Hub - Aston Martin Lagonda   11:04AM The woes of Woodford

Following our story this morning that Neil Woodford could face being ousted from managing his own fund, here's a reminder of just how far his star has fallen:

Woodford's flagship fund has spiraled downwards   10:57AMTakeaway.com shares at all-time high

Over on the Dutch markets, Takeaway.com is at all-time highs, up around 3pc on the day following confirmation of its planned merger with Just Eat (which is up just under 25pc now).

Investors are digesting the takeaway takeover plan, which could perhaps be described as giving Just Eat a Dutch brain transplant.

10:40AM Flashback: When the pound was worth barely a dollar

As the pound hovers near a two-year low, time for a (very) quick history lesson about its lowest-ever level.

Sterling hit its all-time low against the dollar on 1st January 1985,  worth just $1.05, following a surge in the dollar's value amid the impact of Ronald Reagan's economic policies.

Markets Hub - US Dollar

 See, I told you it would be quick.

10:18AM Follow the latest politics updates

No-deal chatter is still rocking the pound, which is at two-year lows. You can follow on the latest updates on the Telegraph's business live blog .

Here's the road ahead for Prime Minister Johnson towards that 31st October Brexit deadline:

The first 100 days of Boris Johnson as PM

It's fair to say many analysts have their doubts about the new PM. Jefferies' Mike Prew and Andrew Gill note:

The record for the shortest PM tenure is held for the time being by George Canning who lasted 5 months (April-August 1827). There are now three months to Halloween.

Spreadex's Connor Campbell adds:

It is effectively a worst-case-scenario end to July for the pound, one that sets up three months of intense Brexit anxiety heading into All Hallows' Eve

Andrew Sentance, formerly part of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, reckons there's still further for sterling to fall:

$1.20 or below here we come ... https://t.co/HVITCA6Y1Ghttps://t.co/HVITCA6Y1G - Andrew Sentance (@asentance)   https://twitter.com/asentance/status/1155752552727818241?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019
10:06AM Reaction to news Vauxhall Astra production will move from Britain 

The Financial Times reported production of the Vauxhall Astra could move from Ellesmere Port to Europe in the event of a "bad" Brexit outcome.

Here's our full repor t, by James Cook.

PSA, Vauxhall's Fresh owner, says:

The decision on the allocation to the Ellesmere Port plant will be conditional on the final terms of the UK's exit from the European Union and the acceptance of the New Vehicle Agreement, which has been negotiated with the Unite Trade Union.

PSA Groupe continues to closely monitor political developments and to engage with policy makers to understand the impact of the various potential Brexit outcomes on our business and suppliers, in order to ensure that the company can continue to operate effectively regardless of the final outcome of Brexit.

Here's Unite's Steve Turner:

Unite is in continuing discussions with PSA. We will not sit back and allow PSA Group to walk away from making cars in the UK to then sell cars made elsewhere back into what is the fifth biggest car market in the world.- Steve Turner (@SteveT_Unite) https://twitter.com/SteveT_Unite/status/1155758070343098368?ref_src=twsrc%5EtfwJuly 29, 2019

Here's a reminder of where the British automotive industry's woes have already had an impact:

Job losses in UK automotive sector   9:55AM Consumer borrowing growth hits five-year low, mortgage growth beats estimates

Consumer borrowing growth in the UK slowed last month, hitting its lowest levels since 2014, the Bank of England has said.

The credit figure, which doesn't include mortgages, grew 5.5pc year-on-year, having steadily dropped since 2016. Meanwhile, Bank figures show lender approved 66,400 mortgages June, beating expectations.

9:51AM Look ahead: Big week for central banks, with decisions from US Fed and Bank of England Monetary Policy Committee

As the FTSE feasts on deal fever, this week looks set to be a significant one for the direction of the world economy, with two rate decisions impending.

Deputy economics editor Tim Wallace writes:

This is an important week for central bankers.

The Federal Reserve in the US is set to cut rates for the first time since 2008 when policymakers meet on Wednesday.

Jerome Powell, the head of the Fed, continued raising rates when he was brought into the job last year. But by the most recent hike in December, markets were panicking and the Fed shifted to a holding pattern.

Now fears of economic weakness are expected to push the Fed to cut again by 0.25 percentage points or more, as the trade war bites and global growth slows.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee sets out its plans on Thursday.

The latest economic forecasts in its Inflation Report will show the expected path of GDP, unemployment and inflation.

Mark Carney and the other policymakers had previously stressed the UK would not join the potential rate cuts at the Fed and the European Central Bank, instead raising rates gradually in the years to come.

But wobbling growth and no-deal Brexit fears mean economists expect Mr Carney to trim back his promises of higher rates.

Are bonds broken?

On the topic of macroeconomics, here's a great bloomberg piece from over the weekend on the often-confusing topic of negative bonds yields, and why people are buying them: The logic behind the bonds that eat your money (£)

The short version: Amid uncertainty, sometimes the safest thing is to know exactly how much you stand to lose (or you don't have a choice anyway).

9:41AMRefinitiv takeover would give LSE Group 'significantly stronger' data position

AJ Bell investment director Russ Mould is seeing the upside in LSE Group's proposed £42bn merger with Refinitiv, which would create a major player in the financial data landscape. He writes:

The market has been waiting for some M&A news from London Stock Exchange ever since David Schwimmer took over as chief executive in 2018. Having previously worked for 20 years at investment bank Goldman Sachs, he is well versed with the art of deal making... 

...Buying Refinitiv would not be a wild card move; in fact, there is a lot of merit to bolting the two companies together. It would provide London Stock Exchange with a significantly stronger position in the field of data. The big challenge is to clear any competition authority hurdles and convince shareholders that it isn't overpaying for the deal.

LSE Group shares are up just under 15pc, trailing only Just Eat. The FTSE is now up over 1pc, spurred by deal talk, to highs not seen since last August.

Markets Hub I FTSE 100   9:29AM Just Eat/Takeaway.com tie-up 'makes sense in the long term'

Lots of reaction is coming in to Just Eat and Takeaway.com's proposed merger . Here's some key details on what the post-merge company could look like, from Michael O'Dwyer's   report :

The deal is structured so that Just Eat's shareholders will receive shares in Amsterdam-listed Takeaway.com in exchange for their shares in Just Eat. The parties want the combined group to be headquartered and domiciled in the Netherlands but to have a premium listing on the London Stock Exchange and to "maintain a significant part of its operations in the United Kingdom", Just Eat said. 

Barclays analysts write: 

In summary, we think this makes sense in the long term. There are relatively few synergies in the near term given little geographical overlap. There will be some from central costs but it isn't a huge number in context - maybe (EURO)20m run rate savings or so. But Just Eat shareholders would be getting the best operator in the space to run the business - a notable shift from missed execution from management in the last few years

Jefferies analysts Giles Thorne and Sebastian Patulea add:

The synergy case for the combination is minimal: there is a tiny operational overlap (Switzerland) and therefore tiny "in-market" consolidation synergies...  In our view, this is primarily about the high esteem Takeaway has for Just Eat, the massive valuation discount and the longer term realisation that if any of the European operators are going to outgun Uber, then size does matter.

9:22AM Round-up: Woodford on the line, Sainsbury's out for delivery

Two top stories from this morning:

Woodford's listed fund shops around for a new manager : Woodford Patient Capital Trust, the publicly listed investment fund formed by embattled stock picker Neil Woodford, is assessing "all options available to it", including replacing Mr Woodford as its fund manager. 

Sainsbury's eyes shock move into restaurant and take-away food market with Uber Eats tie-up : The supermarket giant is considering launching a chain of restaurants as the war for the takeaway food market heats up.

9:11AMSanne Group shares plummet after downgrades

Sanne Group is the biggest black mark on the FTSE 250 today, eclipsing Sports Direct (which is fluctuating at down around 7pc currently).

The fund and trust administrator is down around 30pc, having been stung by analyst downgrades following a trading update this morning that showed weakness in its European operations.

Chief executive Martin Schnaier said : 

The first half margin is a disappointing outcome and well below the optimal margin for the business. We have taken action to address the increased spend and delay in operating efficiencies being realised.

RBC analysts said it was "clearly a disappointing update", while Liberum cut its target price.

Markets Hub - Sanne Group PLC   9:01AM FTSE opens higher, Euro stocks flat

THe FTSE 100 and FTSE 250 have both opened up, despite substantially pressure on the latter from Sanne Group (more on that shortly). On the continent, The major indices are all positive but flat except France's, which is narrowly down.

Here's how the major indices look:

8:58AM Pound sinks to two-year low against dollar amid no-deal talk

Sterling has hit a two-year low against the dollar this morning, as markets absorb increased talk of a no-deal Brexit from the government. Michael Gove, named Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster with responsibility for no-deal planning by Boris Johnson, has said government is "working on the assumption" Britain will leave the EU without a deal in place. The pound bought as little as $1.2336 earlier this morning.

The Telegraph reports this morning that Mr Johnson is preparing a mega ad-spend to prepare Britons for no-deal, while Europe Editor Peter Foster reports on warnings that   a no-deal exit "would leave UK farmers defenceless" .

Here's what that currency weakness means for UK property:

Weak pound and falling prices: how overseas investors are flocking to buy half-price British properties

8:43AMRefinitiv takeover talk lifts LSE Group

London Stock Exchange Group is currently up around 13pc, as traders absorb a Financial Times scoop from Saturday that the stock exchange operator is looking to join forces with Refinitiv, the financial data company that was previously part of Thomson Reuters.

Blackstone poised to become London Stock Exchange's biggest shareholder in Refinitiv deal 

Refinitiv is perhaps best known for its Eikon terminals, computer software that allows investors, traders and analysts (and, yes, business journalists) to access a wide range of financial data. If the deal passes, it will position the newly-merged firm as a major rival to Bloomberg, which has its own terminal product. It will also potentially give LSE Group an edge against continental rivals.

There are potential snags, however. The proposed deal puts the Blackstone-backed consortium that owns Refinitiv in a position of potential power, something the City might not welcome with open arms.   Sources have also told Reuters the tie-up would face substantial scrutiny from competition regulators.  It reports:

Antitrust regulators in Europe and the United States are expected to start an in-depth review which may last up to 18 months, the sources said.

In the European Union, the deal is expected to go into a Phase II investigation, two sources said, a more onerous review used only in deals where there are concerns it will have a major impact on competition.

8:33AM Just Eat and Takeaway.com agree terms of tie-up

FTSE 100 delivery firm Just East and Dutch rival Takeaway.comhave outlined details  of their proposed £9bn all-share merger. Just Eat shareholders would receive a 15pc premium on Friday's closing price, with the join-up leaving them in control of 52pc of the group. 

In a joint statement, the companies said:

The possible combination would create one of the largest online food delivery companies in the world, with scale, strategic vision, industry leading capabilities, leading positions in attractive markets and a diversified geographic presence.

My colleague Michael O'Dwyer has a full report here:

Just Eat shareholders to get 52pc slice after £9bn Takeover.com merger

One big winner from the deal is Cat Rock, a US-based fund which has been agitating for a change of tack at Just Eat, and which (conveniently) owns a substantial chunk of Takeaway.com. Here's more on them and the deal:

Takeaway.com and Just Eat tie-up could have Cat Rock purring

8:23AM Agenda: Deals in the spotlight as City wakes up from big weekend

Good morning, and welcome to our live coverage of business, markets and economics.

It's a big day in the City today, at the start of a potentially crucial week for the world economy. Deal fever struck at the weekend, with revelations of £42 billion tie-up between the London Stock Exchange Group and data provider Refinitiv, and a £9 billion merger between food delivery giant Just Eat and its Dutch rival Takeaway.com.

Details of both are beginning to emerge, and we'll bring you the latest reactions as soon as we get them. Just Eat Shares are up 21.4pc, while LSE Group is up 11.85pc.

Direct impact

Sports Direct had a bit of a day on Friday, with a series of delays to its final results leading one analyst to brand the retailer a "shambles". When it finally did   get itself together  after the bell, it revealed it had been served a £605 million tax bill by Belgian authorities. If you want to relive the entire saga, you can look back over   Friday's (now dead) live blog . Traders are now able to react, and they seem unhappy: shares in the FTSE 250 firm are currently down 14pc, after immediate lows of more than 19pc.

In the diary today...

Interim results: Cranswick, Hammerson, Heineken, Hiscox, Keller Group, Ryanair

AGM: Active Energy, Remote Monitor Systems

Economics: US Dallas fed manufacturing index, UK mortgage approvals and consumer credit
