Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TV7-YVM1-JB20-G19K-00000-00Powell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New "Ladder" Health Products2018-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTKevin Kelly, Michael Lee, Kristin TateNEWSFinancial112801cb.231Powell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New "Ladder" Health ProductsMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti, Jared Max, Mike Huckabee

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. How are you? Thank you so much. Happy Wednesday, ladies. We will see you in a few minutes.

And good morning, everyone, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. We're happy you're here. It is Wednesday, November 28th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump versus Fed Chairman Jay Powell. The President lashing out at Powell again in a new interview with The Washington Post.

It comes ahead of a highly-anticipated speech today from Jay Powell this afternoon, 12:00 noon.

Meanwhile, G-20 countdown is on. The focus on President Trump's working dinner with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday.

The question is whether they make a deal on trade is still up in the air.

And then there's this, a new threat for General Motors.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: There's disappointment that it seems like G.M. would rather build its electric cars in China rather than the United States.

We are going to be looking at certain subsidies regarding electric cars and others, whether they should apply or not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump confirming that possibility. We are looking at the fallout of taking away those subsidies.

Meanwhile, investors showing signs of optimism this morning, take a look at futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages.

Dow Industrials up almost 90 points right now, that's a third of a percent. S&P is also up a third of a percent, and the NASDAQ up 28 points.

We are getting the second reading on the third quarter GDP this morning. We are expecting to show growth of three and a half percent for the GDP for the third quarter.

Markets are up ahead of that.

Gains across the board yesterday as well. The Dow and the S&P 500 now back in positive territory for 2018.

The Dow at the close yesterday up 108 points. The NASDAQ was up eight points and the -- I'm sorry, the NASDAQ was up a fraction under one point, and the S&P 500 was up eight points yesterday at the close, about a third of a percent.

In Europe this morning, the action is mixed. FT-100 pulling back a fraction, but the CAC Quarante is up 21 points, and the DAX Index in Germany up 28 points. It's good enough for a quarter of a percent gain in Germany.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board, take a look at the best performers there, Japan, Hong Kong, China, all up better than one percent overnight.

Cindy Hyde-Smith holds on, the republican beating democrat Mike Espy to keep her Mississippi Senate seat, bringing the latest in that late results.

Plus LeBron James looking beyond basketball. Details on his new venture with Cindy Crawford, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Lindsey Vonn in wellness, offering energy powders and supplements.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to be with you, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Good morning. Hopefully, we get the confirmation of 3.5 percent on the GDP print, so the market's anticipating that.

That's a great quarter.

BARTIROMO: That would be a good quarter.

KELLY: Yes. We need it.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And the President going after General Motors, threatening to take away subsidies, here's the headline.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: The President doesn't have to do anything because that tax credit, it's $7,500 per vehicle, it's going -- it's basically winding down for General Motors in literally the next couple of months because they've hit this threshold.

So, it starts to disappear -- gradually expire so the White House wouldn't have to do anything. They just have to step back and not extend it.

BARTIROMO: Because the subsidies go away on their own.

MCDOWELL: After you hit a 200,000 vehicle mark per manufacturer. Tesla already hit it recently.

General Motors will is going to hit in the next couple of months so gradually expires, this $7,500 tax credit so they can just step and say, "You don't get any more subsidies."

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: But how tone-deaf is G.M. on all this?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: Closing plants right here at Christmas time, they get all these billions of dollars of subsidies from the taxpayers to become Government Motors. I resented it then, I'd been a 35-year G.M. customer, I said I'm done with them.

MCDOWELL: Wow.

HUCKABEE: I haven't had a G.M. product since, won't have another one.

And, you know, then they pull this stunt and I just feel like that they're not thinking very smartly in terms of how they're presenting their company --

MCDOWELL: Well --

HUCKABEE: -- and ingratitude to the American taxpayer.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: White House, the Trump administration could rescind the steel and aluminum tariffs that would save 9,400 jobs, how about that?

HUCKABEE: Well, fine, but you know what, it's the pressure that the Trump administration is putting on these countries in the tariffs that's causing them to get to the point where I hope we have zero tariffs which is what Kudlow wants, which is what the President wants.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: But you don't get there by being a chump which is what is U.S. has been for a long, long time.

KELLY: That's a great point, why don't we get rid of all subsidies to corporations? I'm not getting a subsidy, you're not getting a subsidy --

HUCKABEE: Nope.

KELLY: -- why are we playing favorites with automobile manufacturers? So.

HUCKABEE: We shouldn't be.

BARTIROMO: Well -- and there was the bailout.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

KELLY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And that's why this is such a particularly important story because a few years ago --

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- this is the company that was bailed out. Got a lot on the table, G.M. -- go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, we lost $11.2 billion on that bailout just for General Motors.

KELLY: Crony Capitalism.

MCDOWELL: I just want to point that out.

HUCKABEE: Yup.

BARTIROMO: Big number, yes, you're right.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HUCKABEE: Exactly right, Kevin.

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, Texas Congressman and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Michael Burgess is here.

Congressman Burgess will be joining us this morning, along with Former Chief Economic Adviser under George w. Bush, Ed Lazear, is here.

Rooted Management Co-Chairman and CEO, Bill Rubin, is with us this morning.

Talking about real estate and Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Plus Dr. Mikhail Varshavski back with us. Dr. Mike is going to joining us as well. Lots to talk about there.

But we got to first talk about Jay Powell, under pressure once again. The President continues his campaign against Powell. President Trump criticized the Federal Reserve Chairman yet again yesterday.

In an interview with the post, blaming Powell for the secret declines and layoffs at General Motors.

The President says this. "So far, I'm not even a little bit happy with my selection of Jay, not even a little bit and I'm not blaming anybody, I'm just telling you I think that the fed is way off base with what they're doing."

This comes ahead of Powell's key speech today on monetary policy, he will be speaking to the New York Economic Club today at noontime.

Joining us right now to talk more about all of that is Altium Wealth Portfolio Manager, Market Strategist, Michael Lee.

Michael, good to see you.

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, ALTIUM WEALTH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the President's comments about Jay Powell.

LEE: So it -- the President is a little bit of a victim of his own success in that the economy is taking off so interest rates have to go higher.

And I think people have grown too attached to this zero interest rates for forever and they don't look at Japan and the destruction that it causes to your economy over time.

When you have zero interest rates, it's because you have no growth and no inflation. We need higher interest rates in this country.

I think the fed is being extremely smart and normalizing, I think it's long overdue.

And I think the reason that Powell is there is more to work on the macroprudential, or the regulatory environment of the big banks.

The Federal Reserve should not be telling J.P. Morgan, and Wells Fargo, and Bank of America which loans they can and can't make.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LEE: Right? It just -- it shouldn't work like that.

And when they do it, when they -- when they have this overreaching overregulation, it slows down the entire economy.

So, Powell is there as a banker and an attorney to help move back the regulatory state, more so than a classically trained economist.

So, I think the President made right choice. I think he's unhappy with the reality that rates have to go higher as are a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: Maybe. But, you know, a lot of people also do feel that the Federal Reserve may be going one step too far, not that they are loco, as the President have said, but that maybe you want to wait to assess the impact of these rate hikes.

What do you think?

KELLY: Well --

BARTIROMO: Do you really need four rate hikes this is year?

KELLY: Yes, you do, because even Chairman Powell said we're not even close to neutral, and that's being confirmed by other fed governors, so they say we need to get back to neutral.

And guess what? Guess who would agree with me? Candidate President -- Candidate Trump, not President Trump, but candidate, because he even said interest rates were too low.

And the problem is we're getting a 3.5 percent GDP print now and we're barely at breakeven rates.

If you look at inflation and then you look at where the fed funds rate is, it's barely -- it's barely even there, right?

You can even have negative real interest rates.

So the problem I have with President Trump and what he told "The Washington Post" is he said his gut is stronger than the collective brainpower of the fed because his exact quote was --

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

KELLY: -- "They're making a mistake because I have a gut. My gut tells me more than some -- sometimes than anybody else's brain can ever tell me."

He also said, "I'm doing deals and I'm not being accommodated by the fed." Well, guess what? President Trump, you're not supposed to be accommodated by the fed.

Listen, that's not -- monetary policy is theirs, yours is fiscal policy, and this is the exact problem we had with President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: He didn't do any fiscal policies.

BARTIROMO: And not only that.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: But, Dagen, how are we supposed to be surprised that rates are going higher?

We were at negative. We were at zero for a decade and everybody said, "We got to get back to normal."

MCDOWELL: But I will argue this, like, I'm not going to get my trousers in a twist over President Trump lambasting, say, Jay Powell, we've gotten used to that.

Let's talk about policy over personality. That's -- we're all used to this.

BARTIROMO: Good. Good. Good.

MCDOWELL: The latest -- the latest criticism from President Trump, you know what, that's who the American people elected, number one.

BARTIROMO: Okay. Good. I like it.

MCDOWELL: Number two, here's the other issue, and he does raise. People automatically, who don't like him, want to dismiss him as being a hothead.

He's not being hot-headed about this. He's a real estate developer.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: And he's watching what we all are, that you had a change in the -- basically the tax incentive for owning and buying a home in this country, and the tax plan, you've had home price gains that have slowed for six straight months, existing home sales declined on an annual basis for eight straight months.

Consumer confidence waning a little bit on the expectations about the economy and housing, and he's raising the issue of what is neutral? Are we in an environment where we might not be able to handle as a nation, as a world rates higher that are so-called normal based on where they were in the last 30 or 40 years?

Eight percent mortgage? I don't think that this economy can handle that, so --

BARTIROMO: Right. And I don't think that's normal. Is that normal?

KELLY: That's --

BARTIROMO: Is that the --

KELLY: That's (INAUDIBLE) housing. Housing isn't affordable in a lot of these states, so the problem is this, they should raise rates so you don't have speculation in the housing market.

And that's what they're preventing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

KELLY: That's exactly what they're doing. There's a reason why mortgage rates are going to --

MCDOWELL: That's not their job. Their job isn't to prevent speculation.

KELLY: Their --

MCDOWELL: Their job isn't --

KELLY: Their job is to prevent runaway inflation.

BARTIROMO: Runaway inflation.

MCDOWELL: And that's what --

KELLY: And what happens when housing inflations go up?

BARTIROMO: Where's the runaway inflation?

MCDOWELL: Right. But there's no -- there isn't.

KELLY: There's --

BARTIROMO: There's no inflation.

MCDOWELL: That's what my point is, is that --

KELLY: Inflation is picking up.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not.

KELLY: That's why they're raising rates.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not. And it's actually very, very tame.

KELLY: What housing market are you looking at?

MCDOWELL: It's very, very tame in consumer prices.

LEE: I would argue that credit availability is far more important than the interest rate.

As we went into the financial crisis, this housing boom and bust, it was cost rates were much higher than they are right now.

Thirty-year mortgages were right around five percent, we're not -- we're not back there yet, so as long as mortgages are available and money is available, rates can be much, much higher.

So the problem is, is nobody can get a loan and nobody can get a mortgage and that's changing, and that's moving in the right direction.

So, as rates move higher, okay? And credit availability increases, which it should with Jay Powell as the Chairman of the Fed, which is why I believe he was there in the first place, like this should be all right.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: What happens is when you have these fundamental shifts, everyone pauses, takes a break, and reevaluates, and the -- you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again. That's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what happened since the election has changed that, reevaluates and you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again, that's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what's happened since the election has changed that, okay?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: It's an unpleasant, you know, when the engine -- when the engine moves and the underneath moves, that doesn't always sit well.

We've seen a huge spike in volatility in the markets that I don't think is going to go away, but I think it's short-term pain for long-term gain.

MCDOWELL: Speak -- just speaking of the volatility, though, the front page story in "The Wall Street Journal," the top story in the paper, is the fed is now shifting to a less predictable approach on policymaking.

It will be based less on forecast of how the economists expect it to perform in the coming months and more based on the latest signs of inflation, unemployment and growth, that will increase volatility in the markets.

That's what "The Journal" is trying to say in that article. But --

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, when we get that three and a half percent GDP today, you can expect that we're going to see that rate hike in a week and a half from the Federal Reserve, that fourth rate hike.

Take it to the bank, because I mean we're already expecting the rate hike, but that three and a half percent GDP is only going to suggest more coming.

MCDOWELL: And then I know that Jay Powell's speaking here in New York at noon.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I know you're going to be there.

BARTIROMO: I'm going to be there.

MCDOWELL: We're all going to be watching, so I can't wait to get your read on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But he's got to certainly give us some kind of a vision in terms of where he thinks this is going, monetary policy and the economy in general.

Let's talk China for a minute because China trade tensions have heated up this week ahead of the G-20 Summit later this week.

The President will sit down for a high-stakes dinner with China's Xi Jinping.

National Economic Council Director, Larry Kudlow, floated a possible breakthrough in the trade talks.

He said this yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KUDLOW: The president said there's a good possibility that we can make a deal and he is open to it.

But on the other hand, if these conditions I mentioned a few moments ago are not met and not dealt with, the President has said, look, he's perfectly happy to stand on his tariff policies.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mike Huckabee, what are -- what are your thoughts here actually?

HUCKABEE: Well, I think the President is possibly going to get a deal with China.

But if he doesn't, he's going to continue to play hardball with him --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: -- which is exactly what we ought to be doing.

I'm so proud this President hasn't just rolled over, not just to China but to everybody.

And I know that creates a lot of heartburn for some people because they're used to an establishment traditional approach, but the traditional approach has gotten our heads handed to us.

And this is a President who, when he goes into one of these negotiations, does so with the sense not America Only, but America First.

And a lot of people in the media don't understand the difference between America First and America Only. They think that he's, you know, some nationalist that doesn't care about the place in the world, that's not true.

But he understands he was not elected to be the global president, but the American President and thank God for it.

BARTIROMO: If there's -- if there's one thing people will agree on is that China has been abusing --

HUCKABEE: Terrible.

BARTIROMO: -- has been the bad actor.

HUCKABEE: It's terrible.

BARTIROMO: Has been stealing IP.

Michael, what's priced into the market in terms of a deal or no deal with China at this point?

LEE: Look, I can't imagine anybody thinking that there would be a dramatic breakthrough at this dinner. I would --

BARTIROMO: No deal is (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: I -- maybe some short-term, maybe we kick the can on some of these tariffs down the road.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I think you're right because --

LEE: -- and continue talking, but --

BARTIROMO: -- if we were to see a deal, you got upside potential (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: Yes. You know, if there's a short-term deal, I think stocks rally, but that's short-term.

urn:contentItem:5TVM-BPV1-DY0W-44SS-00000-00Powell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health Products2018-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPowell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health ProductsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. How are you? Thank you so much. Happy Wednesday, ladies. We will see you in a few minutes.

And good morning, everyone, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. We're happy you're here. It is Wednesday, November 28th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump versus Fed Chairman Jay Powell. The President lashing out at Powell again in a new interview with The Washington Post.

It comes ahead of a highly-anticipated speech today from Jay Powell this afternoon, 12:00 noon.

Meanwhile, G-20 countdown is on. The focus on President Trump's working dinner with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday.

The question is whether they make a deal on trade is still up in the air.

And then there's this, a new threat for General Motors.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: There's disappointment that it seems like G.M. would rather build its electric cars in China rather than the United States.

We are going to be looking at certain subsidies regarding electric cars and others, whether they should apply or not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump confirming that possibility. We are looking at the fallout of taking away those subsidies.

Meanwhile, investors showing signs of optimism this morning, take a look at futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages.

Dow Industrials up almost 90 points right now, that's a third of a percent. S&P is also up a third of a percent, and the NASDAQ up 28 points.

We are getting the second reading on the third quarter GDP this morning. We are expecting to show growth of three and a half percent for the GDP for the third quarter.

Markets are up ahead of that.

Gains across the board yesterday as well. The Dow and the S&P 500 now back in positive territory for 2018.

The Dow at the close yesterday up 108 points. The NASDAQ was up eight points and the -- I'm sorry, the NASDAQ was up a fraction under one point, and the S&P 500 was up eight points yesterday at the close, about a third of a percent.

In Europe this morning, the action is mixed. FT-100 pulling back a fraction, but the CAC Quarante is up 21 points, and the DAX Index in Germany up 28 points. It's good enough for a quarter of a percent gain in Germany.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board, take a look at the best performers there, Japan, Hong Kong, China, all up better than one percent overnight.

Cindy Hyde-Smith holds on, the republican beating democrat Mike Espy to keep her Mississippi Senate seat, bringing the latest in that late results.

Plus LeBron James looking beyond basketball. Details on his new venture with Cindy Crawford, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Lindsey Vonn in wellness, offering energy powders and supplements.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to be with you, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Good morning. Hopefully, we get the confirmation of 3.5 percent on the GDP print, so the market's anticipating that.

That's a great quarter.

BARTIROMO: That would be a good quarter.

KELLY: Yes. We need it.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And the President going after General Motors, threatening to take away subsidies, here's the headline.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: The President doesn't have to do anything because that tax credit, it's $7,500 per vehicle, it's going -- it's basically winding down for General Motors in literally the next couple of months because they've hit this threshold.

So, it starts to disappear -- gradually expire so the White House wouldn't have to do anything. They just have to step back and not extend it.

BARTIROMO: Because the subsidies go away on their own.

MCDOWELL: After you hit a 200,000 vehicle mark per manufacturer. Tesla already hit it recently.

General Motors will is going to hit in the next couple of months so gradually expires, this $7,500 tax credit so they can just step and say, "You don't get any more subsidies."

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: But how tone-deaf is G.M. on all this?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: Closing plants right here at Christmas time, they get all these billions of dollars of subsidies from the taxpayers to become Government Motors. I resented it then, I'd been a 35-year G.M. customer, I said I'm done with them.

MCDOWELL: Wow.

HUCKABEE: I haven't had a G.M. product since, won't have another one.

And, you know, then they pull this stunt and I just feel like that they're not thinking very smartly in terms of how they're presenting their company --

MCDOWELL: Well --

HUCKABEE: -- and ingratitude to the American taxpayer.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: White House, the Trump administration could rescind the steel and aluminum tariffs that would save 9,400 jobs, how about that?

HUCKABEE: Well, fine, but you know what, it's the pressure that the Trump administration is putting on these countries in the tariffs that's causing them to get to the point where I hope we have zero tariffs which is what Kudlow wants, which is what the President wants.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: But you don't get there by being a chump which is what is U.S. has been for a long, long time.

KELLY: That's a great point, why don't we get rid of all subsidies to corporations? I'm not getting a subsidy, you're not getting a subsidy --

HUCKABEE: Nope.

KELLY: -- why are we playing favorites with automobile manufacturers? So.

HUCKABEE: We shouldn't be.

BARTIROMO: Well -- and there was the bailout.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

KELLY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And that's why this is such a particularly important story because a few years ago --

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- this is the company that was bailed out. Got a lot on the table, G.M. -- go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, we lost $11.2 billion on that bailout just for General Motors.

KELLY: Crony Capitalism.

MCDOWELL: I just want to point that out.

HUCKABEE: Yup.

BARTIROMO: Big number, yes, you're right.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HUCKABEE: Exactly right, Kevin.

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, Texas Congressman and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Michael Burgess is here.

Congressman Burgess will be joining us this morning, along with Former Chief Economic Adviser under George w. Bush, Ed Lazear, is here.

Rooted Management Co-Chairman and CEO, Bill Rubin, is with us this morning.

Talking about real estate and Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Plus Dr. Mikhail Varshavski back with us. Dr. Mike is going to joining us as well. Lots to talk about there.

But we got to first talk about Jay Powell, under pressure once again. The President continues his campaign against Powell. President Trump criticized the Federal Reserve Chairman yet again yesterday.

In an interview with the post, blaming Powell for the secret declines and layoffs at General Motors.

The President says this. "So far, I'm not even a little bit happy with my selection of Jay, not even a little bit and I'm not blaming anybody, I'm just telling you I think that the fed is way off base with what they're doing."

This comes ahead of Powell's key speech today on monetary policy, he will be speaking to the New York Economic Club today at noontime.

Joining us right now to talk more about all of that is Altium Wealth Portfolio Manager, Market Strategist, Michael Lee.

Michael, good to see you.

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, ALTIUM WEALTH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the President's comments about Jay Powell.

LEE: So it -- the President is a little bit of a victim of his own success in that the economy is taking off so interest rates have to go higher.

And I think people have grown too attached to this zero interest rates for forever and they don't look at Japan and the destruction that it causes to your economy over time.

When you have zero interest rates, it's because you have no growth and no inflation. We need higher interest rates in this country.

I think the fed is being extremely smart and normalizing, I think it's long overdue.

And I think the reason that Powell is there is more to work on the macroprudential, or the regulatory environment of the big banks.

The Federal Reserve should not be telling J.P. Morgan, and Wells Fargo, and Bank of America which loans they can and can't make.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LEE: Right? It just -- it shouldn't work like that.

And when they do it, when they -- when they have this overreaching overregulation, it slows down the entire economy.

So, Powell is there as a banker and an attorney to help move back the regulatory state, more so than a classically trained economist.

So, I think the President made right choice. I think he's unhappy with the reality that rates have to go higher as are a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: Maybe. But, you know, a lot of people also do feel that the Federal Reserve may be going one step too far, not that they are loco, as the President have said, but that maybe you want to wait to assess the impact of these rate hikes.

What do you think?

KELLY: Well --

BARTIROMO: Do you really need four rate hikes this is year?

KELLY: Yes, you do, because even Chairman Powell said we're not even close to neutral, and that's being confirmed by other fed governors, so they say we need to get back to neutral.

And guess what? Guess who would agree with me? Candidate President -- Candidate Trump, not President Trump, but candidate, because he even said interest rates were too low.

And the problem is we're getting a 3.5 percent GDP print now and we're barely at breakeven rates.

If you look at inflation and then you look at where the fed funds rate is, it's barely -- it's barely even there, right?

You can even have negative real interest rates.

So the problem I have with President Trump and what he told "The Washington Post" is he said his gut is stronger than the collective brainpower of the fed because his exact quote was --

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

KELLY: -- "They're making a mistake because I have a gut. My gut tells me more than some -- sometimes than anybody else's brain can ever tell me."

He also said, "I'm doing deals and I'm not being accommodated by the fed." Well, guess what? President Trump, you're not supposed to be accommodated by the fed.

Listen, that's not -- monetary policy is theirs, yours is fiscal policy, and this is the exact problem we had with President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: He didn't do any fiscal policies.

BARTIROMO: And not only that.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: But, Dagen, how are we supposed to be surprised that rates are going higher?

We were at negative. We were at zero for a decade and everybody said, "We got to get back to normal."

MCDOWELL: But I will argue this, like, I'm not going to get my trousers in a twist over President Trump lambasting, say, Jay Powell, we've gotten used to that.

Let's talk about policy over personality. That's -- we're all used to this.

BARTIROMO: Good. Good. Good.

MCDOWELL: The latest -- the latest criticism from President Trump, you know what, that's who the American people elected, number one.

BARTIROMO: Okay. Good. I like it.

MCDOWELL: Number two, here's the other issue, and he does raise. People automatically, who don't like him, want to dismiss him as being a hothead.

He's not being hot-headed about this. He's a real estate developer.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: And he's watching what we all are, that you had a change in the -- basically the tax incentive for owning and buying a home in this country, and the tax plan, you've had home price gains that have slowed for six straight months, existing home sales declined on an annual basis for eight straight months.

Consumer confidence waning a little bit on the expectations about the economy and housing, and he's raising the issue of what is neutral? Are we in an environment where we might not be able to handle as a nation, as a world rates higher that are so-called normal based on where they were in the last 30 or 40 years?

Eight percent mortgage? I don't think that this economy can handle that, so --

BARTIROMO: Right. And I don't think that's normal. Is that normal?

KELLY: That's --

BARTIROMO: Is that the --

KELLY: That's (INAUDIBLE) housing. Housing isn't affordable in a lot of these states, so the problem is this, they should raise rates so you don't have speculation in the housing market.

And that's what they're preventing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

KELLY: That's exactly what they're doing. There's a reason why mortgage rates are going to --

MCDOWELL: That's not their job. Their job isn't to prevent speculation.

KELLY: Their --

MCDOWELL: Their job isn't --

KELLY: Their job is to prevent runaway inflation.

BARTIROMO: Runaway inflation.

MCDOWELL: And that's what --

KELLY: And what happens when housing inflations go up?

BARTIROMO: Where's the runaway inflation?

MCDOWELL: Right. But there's no -- there isn't.

KELLY: There's --

BARTIROMO: There's no inflation.

MCDOWELL: That's what my point is, is that --

KELLY: Inflation is picking up.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not.

KELLY: That's why they're raising rates.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not. And it's actually very, very tame.

KELLY: What housing market are you looking at?

MCDOWELL: It's very, very tame in consumer prices.

LEE: I would argue that credit availability is far more important than the interest rate.

As we went into the financial crisis, this housing boom and bust, it was cost rates were much higher than they are right now.

Thirty-year mortgages were right around five percent, we're not -- we're not back there yet, so as long as mortgages are available and money is available, rates can be much, much higher.

So the problem is, is nobody can get a loan and nobody can get a mortgage and that's changing, and that's moving in the right direction.

So, as rates move higher, okay? And credit availability increases, which it should with Jay Powell as the Chairman of the Fed, which is why I believe he was there in the first place, like this should be all right.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: What happens is when you have these fundamental shifts, everyone pauses, takes a break, and reevaluates, and the -- you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again. That's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what happened since the election has changed that, reevaluates and you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again, that's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what's happened since the election has changed that, okay?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: It's an unpleasant, you know, when the engine -- when the engine moves and the underneath moves, that doesn't always sit well.

We've seen a huge spike in volatility in the markets that I don't think is going to go away, but I think it's short-term pain for long-term gain.

MCDOWELL: Speak -- just speaking of the volatility, though, the front page story in "The Wall Street Journal," the top story in the paper, is the fed is now shifting to a less predictable approach on policymaking.

It will be based less on forecast of how the economists expect it to perform in the coming months and more based on the latest signs of inflation, unemployment and growth, that will increase volatility in the markets.

That's what "The Journal" is trying to say in that article. But --

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, when we get that three and a half percent GDP today, you can expect that we're going to see that rate hike in a week and a half from the Federal Reserve, that fourth rate hike.

Take it to the bank, because I mean we're already expecting the rate hike, but that three and a half percent GDP is only going to suggest more coming.

MCDOWELL: And then I know that Jay Powell's speaking here in New York at noon.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I know you're going to be there.

BARTIROMO: I'm going to be there.

MCDOWELL: We're all going to be watching, so I can't wait to get your read on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But he's got to certainly give us some kind of a vision in terms of where he thinks this is going, monetary policy and the economy in general.

Let's talk China for a minute because China trade tensions have heated up this week ahead of the G-20 Summit later this week.

The President will sit down for a high-stakes dinner with China's Xi Jinping.

National Economic Council Director, Larry Kudlow, floated a possible breakthrough in the trade talks.

He said this yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KUDLOW: The president said there's a good possibility that we can make a deal and he is open to it.

But on the other hand, if these conditions I mentioned a few moments ago are not met and not dealt with, the President has said, look, he's perfectly happy to stand on his tariff policies.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mike Huckabee, what are -- what are your thoughts here actually?

HUCKABEE: Well, I think the President is possibly going to get a deal with China.

But if he doesn't, he's going to continue to play hardball with him --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: -- which is exactly what we ought to be doing.

I'm so proud this President hasn't just rolled over, not just to China but to everybody.

And I know that creates a lot of heartburn for some people because they're used to an establishment traditional approach, but the traditional approach has gotten our heads handed to us.

And this is a President who, when he goes into one of these negotiations, does so with the sense not America Only, but America First.

And a lot of people in the media don't understand the difference between America First and America Only. They think that he's, you know, some nationalist that doesn't care about the place in the world, that's not true.

But he understands he was not elected to be the global president, but the American President and thank God for it.

BARTIROMO: If there's -- if there's one thing people will agree on is that China has been abusing --

HUCKABEE: Terrible.

BARTIROMO: -- has been the bad actor.

HUCKABEE: It's terrible.

BARTIROMO: Has been stealing IP.

Michael, what's priced into the market in terms of a deal or no deal with China at this point?

LEE: Look, I can't imagine anybody thinking that there would be a dramatic breakthrough at this dinner. I would --

BARTIROMO: No deal is (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: I -- maybe some short-term, maybe we kick the can on some of these tariffs down the road.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I think you're right because --

LEE: -- and continue talking, but --

BARTIROMO: -- if we were to see a deal, you got upside potential (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: Yes. You know, if there's a short-term deal, I think stocks rally, but that's short-term.

urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D546-00000-00Powell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health Products2018-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPowell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health ProductsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. How are you? Thank you so much. Happy Wednesday, ladies. We will see you in a few minutes.

And good morning, everyone, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. We're happy you're here. It is Wednesday, November 28th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump versus Fed Chairman Jay Powell. The President lashing out at Powell again in a new interview with The Washington Post.

It comes ahead of a highly-anticipated speech today from Jay Powell this afternoon, 12:00 noon.

Meanwhile, G-20 countdown is on. The focus on President Trump's working dinner with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday.

The question is whether they make a deal on trade is still up in the air.

And then there's this, a new threat for General Motors.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: There's disappointment that it seems like G.M. would rather build its electric cars in China rather than the United States.

We are going to be looking at certain subsidies regarding electric cars and others, whether they should apply or not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump confirming that possibility. We are looking at the fallout of taking away those subsidies.

Meanwhile, investors showing signs of optimism this morning, take a look at futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages.

Dow Industrials up almost 90 points right now, that's a third of a percent. S&P is also up a third of a percent, and the NASDAQ up 28 points.

We are getting the second reading on the third quarter GDP this morning. We are expecting to show growth of three and a half percent for the GDP for the third quarter.

Markets are up ahead of that.

Gains across the board yesterday as well. The Dow and the S&P 500 now back in positive territory for 2018.

The Dow at the close yesterday up 108 points. The NASDAQ was up eight points and the -- I'm sorry, the NASDAQ was up a fraction under one point, and the S&P 500 was up eight points yesterday at the close, about a third of a percent.

In Europe this morning, the action is mixed. FT-100 pulling back a fraction, but the CAC Quarante is up 21 points, and the DAX Index in Germany up 28 points. It's good enough for a quarter of a percent gain in Germany.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board, take a look at the best performers there, Japan, Hong Kong, China, all up better than one percent overnight.

Cindy Hyde-Smith holds on, the republican beating democrat Mike Espy to keep her Mississippi Senate seat, bringing the latest in that late results.

Plus LeBron James looking beyond basketball. Details on his new venture with Cindy Crawford, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Lindsey Vonn in wellness, offering energy powders and supplements.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to be with you, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Good morning. Hopefully, we get the confirmation of 3.5 percent on the GDP print, so the market's anticipating that.

That's a great quarter.

BARTIROMO: That would be a good quarter.

KELLY: Yes. We need it.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And the President going after General Motors, threatening to take away subsidies, here's the headline.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: The President doesn't have to do anything because that tax credit, it's $7,500 per vehicle, it's going -- it's basically winding down for General Motors in literally the next couple of months because they've hit this threshold.

So, it starts to disappear -- gradually expire so the White House wouldn't have to do anything. They just have to step back and not extend it.

BARTIROMO: Because the subsidies go away on their own.

MCDOWELL: After you hit a 200,000 vehicle mark per manufacturer. Tesla already hit it recently.

General Motors will is going to hit in the next couple of months so gradually expires, this $7,500 tax credit so they can just step and say, "You don't get any more subsidies."

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: But how tone-deaf is G.M. on all this?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: Closing plants right here at Christmas time, they get all these billions of dollars of subsidies from the taxpayers to become Government Motors. I resented it then, I'd been a 35-year G.M. customer, I said I'm done with them.

MCDOWELL: Wow.

HUCKABEE: I haven't had a G.M. product since, won't have another one.

And, you know, then they pull this stunt and I just feel like that they're not thinking very smartly in terms of how they're presenting their company --

MCDOWELL: Well --

HUCKABEE: -- and ingratitude to the American taxpayer.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: White House, the Trump administration could rescind the steel and aluminum tariffs that would save 9,400 jobs, how about that?

HUCKABEE: Well, fine, but you know what, it's the pressure that the Trump administration is putting on these countries in the tariffs that's causing them to get to the point where I hope we have zero tariffs which is what Kudlow wants, which is what the President wants.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: But you don't get there by being a chump which is what is U.S. has been for a long, long time.

KELLY: That's a great point, why don't we get rid of all subsidies to corporations? I'm not getting a subsidy, you're not getting a subsidy --

HUCKABEE: Nope.

KELLY: -- why are we playing favorites with automobile manufacturers? So.

HUCKABEE: We shouldn't be.

BARTIROMO: Well -- and there was the bailout.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

KELLY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And that's why this is such a particularly important story because a few years ago --

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- this is the company that was bailed out. Got a lot on the table, G.M. -- go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, we lost $11.2 billion on that bailout just for General Motors.

KELLY: Crony Capitalism.

MCDOWELL: I just want to point that out.

HUCKABEE: Yup.

BARTIROMO: Big number, yes, you're right.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HUCKABEE: Exactly right, Kevin.

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, Texas Congressman and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Michael Burgess is here.

Congressman Burgess will be joining us this morning, along with Former Chief Economic Adviser under George w. Bush, Ed Lazear, is here.

Rooted Management Co-Chairman and CEO, Bill Rubin, is with us this morning.

Talking about real estate and Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Plus Dr. Mikhail Varshavski back with us. Dr. Mike is going to joining us as well. Lots to talk about there.

But we got to first talk about Jay Powell, under pressure once again. The President continues his campaign against Powell. President Trump criticized the Federal Reserve Chairman yet again yesterday.

In an interview with the post, blaming Powell for the secret declines and layoffs at General Motors.

The President says this. "So far, I'm not even a little bit happy with my selection of Jay, not even a little bit and I'm not blaming anybody, I'm just telling you I think that the fed is way off base with what they're doing."

This comes ahead of Powell's key speech today on monetary policy, he will be speaking to the New York Economic Club today at noontime.

Joining us right now to talk more about all of that is Altium Wealth Portfolio Manager, Market Strategist, Michael Lee.

Michael, good to see you.

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, ALTIUM WEALTH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the President's comments about Jay Powell.

LEE: So it -- the President is a little bit of a victim of his own success in that the economy is taking off so interest rates have to go higher.

And I think people have grown too attached to this zero interest rates for forever and they don't look at Japan and the destruction that it causes to your economy over time.

When you have zero interest rates, it's because you have no growth and no inflation. We need higher interest rates in this country.

I think the fed is being extremely smart and normalizing, I think it's long overdue.

And I think the reason that Powell is there is more to work on the macroprudential, or the regulatory environment of the big banks.

The Federal Reserve should not be telling J.P. Morgan, and Wells Fargo, and Bank of America which loans they can and can't make.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LEE: Right? It just -- it shouldn't work like that.

And when they do it, when they -- when they have this overreaching overregulation, it slows down the entire economy.

So, Powell is there as a banker and an attorney to help move back the regulatory state, more so than a classically trained economist.

So, I think the President made right choice. I think he's unhappy with the reality that rates have to go higher as are a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: Maybe. But, you know, a lot of people also do feel that the Federal Reserve may be going one step too far, not that they are loco, as the President have said, but that maybe you want to wait to assess the impact of these rate hikes.

What do you think?

KELLY: Well --

BARTIROMO: Do you really need four rate hikes this is year?

KELLY: Yes, you do, because even Chairman Powell said we're not even close to neutral, and that's being confirmed by other fed governors, so they say we need to get back to neutral.

And guess what? Guess who would agree with me? Candidate President -- Candidate Trump, not President Trump, but candidate, because he even said interest rates were too low.

And the problem is we're getting a 3.5 percent GDP print now and we're barely at breakeven rates.

If you look at inflation and then you look at where the fed funds rate is, it's barely -- it's barely even there, right?

You can even have negative real interest rates.

So the problem I have with President Trump and what he told "The Washington Post" is he said his gut is stronger than the collective brainpower of the fed because his exact quote was --

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

KELLY: -- "They're making a mistake because I have a gut. My gut tells me more than some -- sometimes than anybody else's brain can ever tell me."

He also said, "I'm doing deals and I'm not being accommodated by the fed." Well, guess what? President Trump, you're not supposed to be accommodated by the fed.

Listen, that's not -- monetary policy is theirs, yours is fiscal policy, and this is the exact problem we had with President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: He didn't do any fiscal policies.

BARTIROMO: And not only that.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: But, Dagen, how are we supposed to be surprised that rates are going higher?

We were at negative. We were at zero for a decade and everybody said, "We got to get back to normal."

MCDOWELL: But I will argue this, like, I'm not going to get my trousers in a twist over President Trump lambasting, say, Jay Powell, we've gotten used to that.

Let's talk about policy over personality. That's -- we're all used to this.

BARTIROMO: Good. Good. Good.

MCDOWELL: The latest -- the latest criticism from President Trump, you know what, that's who the American people elected, number one.

BARTIROMO: Okay. Good. I like it.

MCDOWELL: Number two, here's the other issue, and he does raise. People automatically, who don't like him, want to dismiss him as being a hothead.

He's not being hot-headed about this. He's a real estate developer.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: And he's watching what we all are, that you had a change in the -- basically the tax incentive for owning and buying a home in this country, and the tax plan, you've had home price gains that have slowed for six straight months, existing home sales declined on an annual basis for eight straight months.

Consumer confidence waning a little bit on the expectations about the economy and housing, and he's raising the issue of what is neutral? Are we in an environment where we might not be able to handle as a nation, as a world rates higher that are so-called normal based on where they were in the last 30 or 40 years?

Eight percent mortgage? I don't think that this economy can handle that, so --

BARTIROMO: Right. And I don't think that's normal. Is that normal?

KELLY: That's --

BARTIROMO: Is that the --

KELLY: That's (INAUDIBLE) housing. Housing isn't affordable in a lot of these states, so the problem is this, they should raise rates so you don't have speculation in the housing market.

And that's what they're preventing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

KELLY: That's exactly what they're doing. There's a reason why mortgage rates are going to --

MCDOWELL: That's not their job. Their job isn't to prevent speculation.

KELLY: Their --

MCDOWELL: Their job isn't --

KELLY: Their job is to prevent runaway inflation.

BARTIROMO: Runaway inflation.

MCDOWELL: And that's what --

KELLY: And what happens when housing inflations go up?

BARTIROMO: Where's the runaway inflation?

MCDOWELL: Right. But there's no -- there isn't.

KELLY: There's --

BARTIROMO: There's no inflation.

MCDOWELL: That's what my point is, is that --

KELLY: Inflation is picking up.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not.

KELLY: That's why they're raising rates.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not. And it's actually very, very tame.

KELLY: What housing market are you looking at?

MCDOWELL: It's very, very tame in consumer prices.

LEE: I would argue that credit availability is far more important than the interest rate.

As we went into the financial crisis, this housing boom and bust, it was cost rates were much higher than they are right now.

Thirty-year mortgages were right around five percent, we're not -- we're not back there yet, so as long as mortgages are available and money is available, rates can be much, much higher.

So the problem is, is nobody can get a loan and nobody can get a mortgage and that's changing, and that's moving in the right direction.

So, as rates move higher, okay? And credit availability increases, which it should with Jay Powell as the Chairman of the Fed, which is why I believe he was there in the first place, like this should be all right.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: What happens is when you have these fundamental shifts, everyone pauses, takes a break, and reevaluates, and the -- you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again. That's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what happened since the election has changed that, reevaluates and you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again, that's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what's happened since the election has changed that, okay?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: It's an unpleasant, you know, when the engine -- when the engine moves and the underneath moves, that doesn't always sit well.

We've seen a huge spike in volatility in the markets that I don't think is going to go away, but I think it's short-term pain for long-term gain.

MCDOWELL: Speak -- just speaking of the volatility, though, the front page story in "The Wall Street Journal," the top story in the paper, is the fed is now shifting to a less predictable approach on policymaking.

It will be based less on forecast of how the economists expect it to perform in the coming months and more based on the latest signs of inflation, unemployment and growth, that will increase volatility in the markets.

That's what "The Journal" is trying to say in that article. But --

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, when we get that three and a half percent GDP today, you can expect that we're going to see that rate hike in a week and a half from the Federal Reserve, that fourth rate hike.

Take it to the bank, because I mean we're already expecting the rate hike, but that three and a half percent GDP is only going to suggest more coming.

MCDOWELL: And then I know that Jay Powell's speaking here in New York at noon.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I know you're going to be there.

BARTIROMO: I'm going to be there.

MCDOWELL: We're all going to be watching, so I can't wait to get your read on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But he's got to certainly give us some kind of a vision in terms of where he thinks this is going, monetary policy and the economy in general.

Let's talk China for a minute because China trade tensions have heated up this week ahead of the G-20 Summit later this week.

The President will sit down for a high-stakes dinner with China's Xi Jinping.

National Economic Council Director, Larry Kudlow, floated a possible breakthrough in the trade talks.

He said this yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KUDLOW: The president said there's a good possibility that we can make a deal and he is open to it.

But on the other hand, if these conditions I mentioned a few moments ago are not met and not dealt with, the President has said, look, he's perfectly happy to stand on his tariff policies.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mike Huckabee, what are -- what are your thoughts here actually?

HUCKABEE: Well, I think the President is possibly going to get a deal with China.

But if he doesn't, he's going to continue to play hardball with him --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: -- which is exactly what we ought to be doing.

I'm so proud this President hasn't just rolled over, not just to China but to everybody.

And I know that creates a lot of heartburn for some people because they're used to an establishment traditional approach, but the traditional approach has gotten our heads handed to us.

And this is a President who, when he goes into one of these negotiations, does so with the sense not America Only, but America First.

And a lot of people in the media don't understand the difference between America First and America Only. They think that he's, you know, some nationalist that doesn't care about the place in the world, that's not true.

But he understands he was not elected to be the global president, but the American President and thank God for it.

BARTIROMO: If there's -- if there's one thing people will agree on is that China has been abusing --

HUCKABEE: Terrible.

BARTIROMO: -- has been the bad actor.

HUCKABEE: It's terrible.

BARTIROMO: Has been stealing IP.

Michael, what's priced into the market in terms of a deal or no deal with China at this point?

LEE: Look, I can't imagine anybody thinking that there would be a dramatic breakthrough at this dinner. I would --

BARTIROMO: No deal is (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: I -- maybe some short-term, maybe we kick the can on some of these tariffs down the road.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I think you're right because --

LEE: -- and continue talking, but --

BARTIROMO: -- if we were to see a deal, you got upside potential (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: Yes. You know, if there's a short-term deal, I think stocks rally, but that's short-term.

This -- you know, the Cold War went on for like 50 years, this is not going away.

The goal of Chinese is to dominate the world, the goal of the U.S. is to open up markets and for peace and prosperity.

BARTIROMO: And to stay the number one country, but China's coming quickly.

You -- any final thought on China (INAUDIBLE)

KELLY: Yes. I mean listen, there's not going to be a deal done, and they've got their 2035 plan, their 2049 plan on top of their 2025 plan. There's (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Meaning they want to be number one in all the important industries.

KELLY: Yes, including military.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Michael, good to see you. Thanks so much.

LEE: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Michael Lee there. Count-up, Mississippi has voted, a big win for President Trump as Cindy Hyde-Smith becomes first Female Senator elected in the Magnolia State.

Then climbing the ladder, how celebrities like LeBron James are teaming up to create their very own wellness brands of protein powders and supplements coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Cindy Hyde-Smith first woman ever elected to Congress from Mississippi. Cheryl Casone with the details now with headlines. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria.

Hyde-Smith defeated democrat Mike Espy in a Senate runoff election after President Trump visited the state on her behalf, holding not one but two rallies.

Hyde-Smith thanked the President during her victory speech last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CINDY HYDE-SMITH (R), MISSISSIPPI: Thank you so much for everything, for the opportunities, for coming to Mississippi yesterday, two stops, phenomenal.

Tupelo was unbelievable, the Coast was unbelievable. We got to ride together and I sure appreciated the time that he gave me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: President Trump tweeting, "Congratulations to Senator Cindy Hyde- Smith on your big win in the Great State of Mississippi. We are all very proud of you."

With her win, the GOP has expanded its Senate majority now to 53 seats.

Well, Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, and Secretary of Defense, James Mattis, going to be brief Senators today on Saudi Arabia.

Lawmakers are pressing the administration on its relationship with the country amid its involvement in the war in Yemen, and the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
