Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VMV-VTK1-JBHT-D09N-00000-00Powell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health Products2018-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPowell Under Pressure; Hyde-Smith Beats Espy; Bitcoin Recovers Lightly; The President Versus The Fed; GOP Unveils Tax Plan; Obama Takes A Veiled Swipe At Trump Saying His Administration Had No Indictments; Google Employees Urge Company To End Dragonfly Project; MLB Is Entering Sports Betting Business In New Deal With MGM; Celebs Team Up For New 'Ladder' Health ProductsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, ladies. How are you? Thank you so much. Happy Wednesday, ladies. We will see you in a few minutes.

And good morning, everyone, thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo. We're happy you're here. It is Wednesday, November 28th.

Your top stories right now just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump versus Fed Chairman Jay Powell. The President lashing out at Powell again in a new interview with The Washington Post.

It comes ahead of a highly-anticipated speech today from Jay Powell this afternoon, 12:00 noon.

Meanwhile, G-20 countdown is on. The focus on President Trump's working dinner with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Saturday.

The question is whether they make a deal on trade is still up in the air.

And then there's this, a new threat for General Motors.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: There's disappointment that it seems like G.M. would rather build its electric cars in China rather than the United States.

We are going to be looking at certain subsidies regarding electric cars and others, whether they should apply or not.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: President Trump confirming that possibility. We are looking at the fallout of taking away those subsidies.

Meanwhile, investors showing signs of optimism this morning, take a look at futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages.

Dow Industrials up almost 90 points right now, that's a third of a percent. S&P is also up a third of a percent, and the NASDAQ up 28 points.

We are getting the second reading on the third quarter GDP this morning. We are expecting to show growth of three and a half percent for the GDP for the third quarter.

Markets are up ahead of that.

Gains across the board yesterday as well. The Dow and the S&P 500 now back in positive territory for 2018.

The Dow at the close yesterday up 108 points. The NASDAQ was up eight points and the -- I'm sorry, the NASDAQ was up a fraction under one point, and the S&P 500 was up eight points yesterday at the close, about a third of a percent.

In Europe this morning, the action is mixed. FT-100 pulling back a fraction, but the CAC Quarante is up 21 points, and the DAX Index in Germany up 28 points. It's good enough for a quarter of a percent gain in Germany.

In Asia overnight, gains across the board, take a look at the best performers there, Japan, Hong Kong, China, all up better than one percent overnight.

Cindy Hyde-Smith holds on, the republican beating democrat Mike Espy to keep her Mississippi Senate seat, bringing the latest in that late results.

Plus LeBron James looking beyond basketball. Details on his new venture with Cindy Crawford, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Lindsey Vonn in wellness, offering energy powders and supplements.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning.

And joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Benchmark Managing Partner, Kevin Kelly, and former Arkansas Governor, Republican Presidential Candidate, Mike Huckabee.

Great to see you this morning.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Great to be with you, Maria. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Good morning.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, BENCHMARK: Good morning. Hopefully, we get the confirmation of 3.5 percent on the GDP print, so the market's anticipating that.

That's a great quarter.

BARTIROMO: That would be a good quarter.

KELLY: Yes. We need it.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And the President going after General Motors, threatening to take away subsidies, here's the headline.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: The President doesn't have to do anything because that tax credit, it's $7,500 per vehicle, it's going -- it's basically winding down for General Motors in literally the next couple of months because they've hit this threshold.

So, it starts to disappear -- gradually expire so the White House wouldn't have to do anything. They just have to step back and not extend it.

BARTIROMO: Because the subsidies go away on their own.

MCDOWELL: After you hit a 200,000 vehicle mark per manufacturer. Tesla already hit it recently.

General Motors will is going to hit in the next couple of months so gradually expires, this $7,500 tax credit so they can just step and say, "You don't get any more subsidies."

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HUCKABEE: But how tone-deaf is G.M. on all this?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: Closing plants right here at Christmas time, they get all these billions of dollars of subsidies from the taxpayers to become Government Motors. I resented it then, I'd been a 35-year G.M. customer, I said I'm done with them.

MCDOWELL: Wow.

HUCKABEE: I haven't had a G.M. product since, won't have another one.

And, you know, then they pull this stunt and I just feel like that they're not thinking very smartly in terms of how they're presenting their company --

MCDOWELL: Well --

HUCKABEE: -- and ingratitude to the American taxpayer.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: White House, the Trump administration could rescind the steel and aluminum tariffs that would save 9,400 jobs, how about that?

HUCKABEE: Well, fine, but you know what, it's the pressure that the Trump administration is putting on these countries in the tariffs that's causing them to get to the point where I hope we have zero tariffs which is what Kudlow wants, which is what the President wants.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: But you don't get there by being a chump which is what is U.S. has been for a long, long time.

KELLY: That's a great point, why don't we get rid of all subsidies to corporations? I'm not getting a subsidy, you're not getting a subsidy --

HUCKABEE: Nope.

KELLY: -- why are we playing favorites with automobile manufacturers? So.

HUCKABEE: We shouldn't be.

BARTIROMO: Well -- and there was the bailout.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

KELLY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: And that's why this is such a particularly important story because a few years ago --

KELLY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- this is the company that was bailed out. Got a lot on the table, G.M. -- go ahead, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, we lost $11.2 billion on that bailout just for General Motors.

KELLY: Crony Capitalism.

MCDOWELL: I just want to point that out.

HUCKABEE: Yup.

BARTIROMO: Big number, yes, you're right.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

HUCKABEE: Exactly right, Kevin.

BARTIROMO: Joining the conversation this morning, Texas Congressman and member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Michael Burgess is here.

Congressman Burgess will be joining us this morning, along with Former Chief Economic Adviser under George w. Bush, Ed Lazear, is here.

Rooted Management Co-Chairman and CEO, Bill Rubin, is with us this morning.

Talking about real estate and Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Plus Dr. Mikhail Varshavski back with us. Dr. Mike is going to joining us as well. Lots to talk about there.

But we got to first talk about Jay Powell, under pressure once again. The President continues his campaign against Powell. President Trump criticized the Federal Reserve Chairman yet again yesterday.

In an interview with the post, blaming Powell for the secret declines and layoffs at General Motors.

The President says this. "So far, I'm not even a little bit happy with my selection of Jay, not even a little bit and I'm not blaming anybody, I'm just telling you I think that the fed is way off base with what they're doing."

This comes ahead of Powell's key speech today on monetary policy, he will be speaking to the New York Economic Club today at noontime.

Joining us right now to talk more about all of that is Altium Wealth Portfolio Manager, Market Strategist, Michael Lee.

Michael, good to see you.

MICHAEL LEE, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, ALTIUM WEALTH: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the President's comments about Jay Powell.

LEE: So it -- the President is a little bit of a victim of his own success in that the economy is taking off so interest rates have to go higher.

And I think people have grown too attached to this zero interest rates for forever and they don't look at Japan and the destruction that it causes to your economy over time.

When you have zero interest rates, it's because you have no growth and no inflation. We need higher interest rates in this country.

I think the fed is being extremely smart and normalizing, I think it's long overdue.

And I think the reason that Powell is there is more to work on the macroprudential, or the regulatory environment of the big banks.

The Federal Reserve should not be telling J.P. Morgan, and Wells Fargo, and Bank of America which loans they can and can't make.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

LEE: Right? It just -- it shouldn't work like that.

And when they do it, when they -- when they have this overreaching overregulation, it slows down the entire economy.

So, Powell is there as a banker and an attorney to help move back the regulatory state, more so than a classically trained economist.

So, I think the President made right choice. I think he's unhappy with the reality that rates have to go higher as are a lot of people.

BARTIROMO: Maybe. But, you know, a lot of people also do feel that the Federal Reserve may be going one step too far, not that they are loco, as the President have said, but that maybe you want to wait to assess the impact of these rate hikes.

What do you think?

KELLY: Well --

BARTIROMO: Do you really need four rate hikes this is year?

KELLY: Yes, you do, because even Chairman Powell said we're not even close to neutral, and that's being confirmed by other fed governors, so they say we need to get back to neutral.

And guess what? Guess who would agree with me? Candidate President -- Candidate Trump, not President Trump, but candidate, because he even said interest rates were too low.

And the problem is we're getting a 3.5 percent GDP print now and we're barely at breakeven rates.

If you look at inflation and then you look at where the fed funds rate is, it's barely -- it's barely even there, right?

You can even have negative real interest rates.

So the problem I have with President Trump and what he told "The Washington Post" is he said his gut is stronger than the collective brainpower of the fed because his exact quote was --

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

KELLY: -- "They're making a mistake because I have a gut. My gut tells me more than some -- sometimes than anybody else's brain can ever tell me."

He also said, "I'm doing deals and I'm not being accommodated by the fed." Well, guess what? President Trump, you're not supposed to be accommodated by the fed.

Listen, that's not -- monetary policy is theirs, yours is fiscal policy, and this is the exact problem we had with President Trump.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KELLY: He didn't do any fiscal policies.

BARTIROMO: And not only that.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: But, Dagen, how are we supposed to be surprised that rates are going higher?

We were at negative. We were at zero for a decade and everybody said, "We got to get back to normal."

MCDOWELL: But I will argue this, like, I'm not going to get my trousers in a twist over President Trump lambasting, say, Jay Powell, we've gotten used to that.

Let's talk about policy over personality. That's -- we're all used to this.

BARTIROMO: Good. Good. Good.

MCDOWELL: The latest -- the latest criticism from President Trump, you know what, that's who the American people elected, number one.

BARTIROMO: Okay. Good. I like it.

MCDOWELL: Number two, here's the other issue, and he does raise. People automatically, who don't like him, want to dismiss him as being a hothead.

He's not being hot-headed about this. He's a real estate developer.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: And he's watching what we all are, that you had a change in the -- basically the tax incentive for owning and buying a home in this country, and the tax plan, you've had home price gains that have slowed for six straight months, existing home sales declined on an annual basis for eight straight months.

Consumer confidence waning a little bit on the expectations about the economy and housing, and he's raising the issue of what is neutral? Are we in an environment where we might not be able to handle as a nation, as a world rates higher that are so-called normal based on where they were in the last 30 or 40 years?

Eight percent mortgage? I don't think that this economy can handle that, so --

BARTIROMO: Right. And I don't think that's normal. Is that normal?

KELLY: That's --

BARTIROMO: Is that the --

KELLY: That's (INAUDIBLE) housing. Housing isn't affordable in a lot of these states, so the problem is this, they should raise rates so you don't have speculation in the housing market.

And that's what they're preventing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

KELLY: That's exactly what they're doing. There's a reason why mortgage rates are going to --

MCDOWELL: That's not their job. Their job isn't to prevent speculation.

KELLY: Their --

MCDOWELL: Their job isn't --

KELLY: Their job is to prevent runaway inflation.

BARTIROMO: Runaway inflation.

MCDOWELL: And that's what --

KELLY: And what happens when housing inflations go up?

BARTIROMO: Where's the runaway inflation?

MCDOWELL: Right. But there's no -- there isn't.

KELLY: There's --

BARTIROMO: There's no inflation.

MCDOWELL: That's what my point is, is that --

KELLY: Inflation is picking up.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not.

KELLY: That's why they're raising rates.

MCDOWELL: Not in housing, it's not. And it's actually very, very tame.

KELLY: What housing market are you looking at?

MCDOWELL: It's very, very tame in consumer prices.

LEE: I would argue that credit availability is far more important than the interest rate.

As we went into the financial crisis, this housing boom and bust, it was cost rates were much higher than they are right now.

Thirty-year mortgages were right around five percent, we're not -- we're not back there yet, so as long as mortgages are available and money is available, rates can be much, much higher.

So the problem is, is nobody can get a loan and nobody can get a mortgage and that's changing, and that's moving in the right direction.

So, as rates move higher, okay? And credit availability increases, which it should with Jay Powell as the Chairman of the Fed, which is why I believe he was there in the first place, like this should be all right.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: What happens is when you have these fundamental shifts, everyone pauses, takes a break, and reevaluates, and the -- you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again. That's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what happened since the election has changed that, reevaluates and you have a lot of very smart people thinking that interest rates would never go up again, that's changing.

Like, you know, President Trump and his fiscal stimulus and what's happened since the election has changed that, okay?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

LEE: It's an unpleasant, you know, when the engine -- when the engine moves and the underneath moves, that doesn't always sit well.

We've seen a huge spike in volatility in the markets that I don't think is going to go away, but I think it's short-term pain for long-term gain.

MCDOWELL: Speak -- just speaking of the volatility, though, the front page story in "The Wall Street Journal," the top story in the paper, is the fed is now shifting to a less predictable approach on policymaking.

It will be based less on forecast of how the economists expect it to perform in the coming months and more based on the latest signs of inflation, unemployment and growth, that will increase volatility in the markets.

That's what "The Journal" is trying to say in that article. But --

BARTIROMO: And don't forget, when we get that three and a half percent GDP today, you can expect that we're going to see that rate hike in a week and a half from the Federal Reserve, that fourth rate hike.

Take it to the bank, because I mean we're already expecting the rate hike, but that three and a half percent GDP is only going to suggest more coming.

MCDOWELL: And then I know that Jay Powell's speaking here in New York at noon.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I know you're going to be there.

BARTIROMO: I'm going to be there.

MCDOWELL: We're all going to be watching, so I can't wait to get your read on that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But he's got to certainly give us some kind of a vision in terms of where he thinks this is going, monetary policy and the economy in general.

Let's talk China for a minute because China trade tensions have heated up this week ahead of the G-20 Summit later this week.

The President will sit down for a high-stakes dinner with China's Xi Jinping.

National Economic Council Director, Larry Kudlow, floated a possible breakthrough in the trade talks.

He said this yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KUDLOW: The president said there's a good possibility that we can make a deal and he is open to it.

But on the other hand, if these conditions I mentioned a few moments ago are not met and not dealt with, the President has said, look, he's perfectly happy to stand on his tariff policies.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Mike Huckabee, what are -- what are your thoughts here actually?

HUCKABEE: Well, I think the President is possibly going to get a deal with China.

But if he doesn't, he's going to continue to play hardball with him --

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HUCKABEE: -- which is exactly what we ought to be doing.

I'm so proud this President hasn't just rolled over, not just to China but to everybody.

And I know that creates a lot of heartburn for some people because they're used to an establishment traditional approach, but the traditional approach has gotten our heads handed to us.

And this is a President who, when he goes into one of these negotiations, does so with the sense not America Only, but America First.

And a lot of people in the media don't understand the difference between America First and America Only. They think that he's, you know, some nationalist that doesn't care about the place in the world, that's not true.

But he understands he was not elected to be the global president, but the American President and thank God for it.

BARTIROMO: If there's -- if there's one thing people will agree on is that China has been abusing --

HUCKABEE: Terrible.

BARTIROMO: -- has been the bad actor.

HUCKABEE: It's terrible.

BARTIROMO: Has been stealing IP.

Michael, what's priced into the market in terms of a deal or no deal with China at this point?

LEE: Look, I can't imagine anybody thinking that there would be a dramatic breakthrough at this dinner. I would --

BARTIROMO: No deal is (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: I -- maybe some short-term, maybe we kick the can on some of these tariffs down the road.

BARTIROMO: Oh, I think you're right because --

LEE: -- and continue talking, but --

BARTIROMO: -- if we were to see a deal, you got upside potential (INAUDIBLE)

LEE: Yes. You know, if there's a short-term deal, I think stocks rally, but that's short-term.

This -- you know, the Cold War went on for like 50 years, this is not going away.

The goal of Chinese is to dominate the world, the goal of the U.S. is to open up markets and for peace and prosperity.

BARTIROMO: And to stay the number one country, but China's coming quickly.

You -- any final thought on China (INAUDIBLE)

KELLY: Yes. I mean listen, there's not going to be a deal done, and they've got their 2035 plan, their 2049 plan on top of their 2025 plan. There's (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: Meaning they want to be number one in all the important industries.

KELLY: Yes, including military.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Michael, good to see you. Thanks so much.

LEE: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Michael Lee there. Count-up, Mississippi has voted, a big win for President Trump as Cindy Hyde-Smith becomes first Female Senator elected in the Magnolia State.

Then climbing the ladder, how celebrities like LeBron James are teaming up to create their very own wellness brands of protein powders and supplements coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Cindy Hyde-Smith first woman ever elected to Congress from Mississippi. Cheryl Casone with the details now with headlines. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria.

Hyde-Smith defeated democrat Mike Espy in a Senate runoff election after President Trump visited the state on her behalf, holding not one but two rallies.

Hyde-Smith thanked the President during her victory speech last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CINDY HYDE-SMITH (R), MISSISSIPPI: Thank you so much for everything, for the opportunities, for coming to Mississippi yesterday, two stops, phenomenal.

Tupelo was unbelievable, the Coast was unbelievable. We got to ride together and I sure appreciated the time that he gave me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: President Trump tweeting, "Congratulations to Senator Cindy Hyde- Smith on your big win in the Great State of Mississippi. We are all very proud of you."

With her win, the GOP has expanded its Senate majority now to 53 seats.

Well, Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, and Secretary of Defense, James Mattis, going to be brief Senators today on Saudi Arabia.

Lawmakers are pressing the administration on its relationship with the country amid its involvement in the war in Yemen, and the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

Notably absent from the meeting is going to be CIA Director, Gina Haspel, the only one of the three reported to have listened to the audio that allegedly depicts the killing of Khashoggi. And several senators are calling for her to appear.

Meanwhile, Pompeo wrote an op-ed in "The Wall Street Journal" stressing the importance of the Saudi-U.S. relationship, calling it a powerful force for stability in the Middle East.

Maria recently spoke with Prince bin -- Al-Waleed bin Talal.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: A month ago, a brutal murder of Jamal Khashoggi, where his body was dismembered, is Mohammed bin Salman for real or is he lying to us about this modernization plan?

AL-WALEED BIN TALAL, PRINCE SAUDI: As for the Jamal Khashoggi incident, you know, you have to understand, Jamal was not only my friend, he was working with me.

Actually, his last job in Saudi Arabia was me and the Arab Channel.

And I like to give through you my condolences, again, to his family, to his wife, ex-wife, and to his children, and to his family because Jamal was a reformer. He was no opposition at all.

And what took place in that Saudi Consulate was clearly horrific --

BARTIROMO: Right.

BIN TALAL: -- despicable, and tragic and I believe that Saudi Arabia is going to get to the bottom of it, but, please, you have to give us some time until the investigation is done and made public by the Government of Saudi Arabia.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CASONE: All right. Another headlines this morning, the price of Bitcoin has bounced back slightly, now hovering around $4,000.

Bitcoin plummeted as low as 3,600 last week amid concerns in the cryptocurrency markets.

A selloff coming after the head of SEC warned a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund is unlikely any time soon. Maria. And those --

BARTIROMO: No, interesting that he said that about an ETF.

CASONE: Yes.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XNC-G9Y1-JBKS-P1CW-00000-00Power Business Spin-Offs: Is This the New Normal?2019-12-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisPower Business Spin-Offs: Is This the New Normal?Jim.dukart

In December 2018, Hitachi Ltd. announced an agreement to buy ABB’s Power Grids business for US$6.4 billion. On the Hitachi side, the move was seen as a grid grab that would enable the Japanese conglomerate to compete head-to-head with the likes of General Electric and Siemens AG in the electric sector. Not more than a few months later, General Electric began selling off many of its power businesses, while Siemens spun its gas and power businesses off into an as-yet-to-be-named entity with the placeholder name of “NewCo."



What might be behind some of these power play spin-offs? And, are there more to come?

Behind the Spin-Offs

The first factor seems to be activist investors pushing for simplified pure-play companies. For ABB, that meant dropping its lower-margins grid business to focus on robotics and factory automation. In addition to carrying ABB’s lowest return on assets in 2018, the company’s grids business saw its third consecutive quarterly slide in the third quarter of 2018.

On the other hand, Hitachi has almost 800 separate businesses, spanning from construction machinery to health care and nuclear power. The company has stated it wants to streamline and focus on four core areas going forward—one of which is power and energy, thus the reason for ABB’s Power Grids business.

Hitachi may have other things in mind, as well. For instance, by getting a piece of the power grid, the company may be able to help drive a global shift away from coal and toward renewable energy. The company also may be lining up grid services as a platform on which to deploy and connect its equipment to the massive internet of things (IoT) market, connecting sensors and devices through the internet for building controls in homes and businesses that can marry the opportunity of smart devices and smart buildings with the smart electric grid Hitachi will now help to build.

“We believe that both companies will complement each other," said Anders Sjoelin, lead division manager, ABB Power Grids North America. “Together, they cover the global energy value chain from generation to transmission and distribution. In addition, Hitachi sees areas like the integration of renewables into the power grid, smart mobility and cities as strategic pillars where ABB Power Grids can contribute significantly with its leading technology solutions."

The Siemens spin-off is of a slightly different nature, but perhaps has a similar goal. In May 2019, the German-based industrial giant announced the spin-off of its Gas & Power (GP) businesses as part of its Vision 2020+ strategy to focus its core competencies on digital industries and smart infrastructure. To be formed out of what was Siemens GP, the new company will be an independent one in which Siemens projects to have 30 billion Euros in orders and 80,000 employees — based on former GP staff and the transfer of the Siemens’ renewable energy business, Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy (SGRE).

“With Vision 2020+, we’re further sharpening Siemens’ focus and making our businesses faster and more flexible," said Joe Kaeser, president and CEO of Siemens, in a conference call with reporters announcing the move. “These changes are laying the foundation for sustainable economic success in growth markets that will be attractive over the long term. We’re also creating solid perspectives for those businesses that have to prove themselves in the structural transformation now underway and address new growth fields."

Kaeser added the new company will be well-positioned to offer a wide range of services in the electric industry, from power generation through gas-fired turbines and wind turbines to oil and gas services and high-voltage transmission. “The success of Siemens’ businesses of the next generation will be determined by new factors," said Kaeser. “Breadth, size and a one-size-fits-all approach will be replaced by focus, speed and adaptability."

Meanwhile, Lisa Davis, who has been CEO of Siemens GP for the last five years, will take over the reins of NewCo. She touts the new company’s independence from Siemens as well as the opportunity to offer a wide range of power services in its new incarnation. “Being independent will enable us to more effectively leverage our position of strength to further support our customers in rapidly changing energy markets," Davis said. “Global electrification continues to be vital to economic and environmental progress around the world and, as the only company with a leading portfolio along the entire energy value chain—in both conventional and renewable energy—we are uniquely able to help both public- and private-sector customers benefit from these developments."

For Siemens, the company’s Digital Industries and Smart Infrastructure operating companies will comprise its future industrial core, to be supplemented by company-wide technology and service units such as Siemens Healthineers and Siemens Mobility. Plans call for NewCo to be completely spun off with its own stock exchange listing in September 2020.

General Electric also is in the game of selling off power divisions. In March 2019, the company unveiled a $3.25 billion deal to sell its distributed power business, focused on the building of smaller gas-fired turbines used in backup, remote or cogeneration power opportunities. The sale to private equity firm Advent International includes the company’s Jenbacher and Waukesha brands as well as manufacturing plants in the U.S., Canada and Austria.

GE’s rationale apparently is different from that of ABB or Siemens, however. The company must shrink itself to pay down significant debt, a result of years of troubled acquisitions. Earlier this year, GE was kicked out of the Dow Industrial Average after more than a century on the prestigious company stock listing. For GE, the distributed power business is just the latest in a line of businesses being spun off, including both its fabled light bulb unit and GE Transportation, the company’s 111-year-old railroad division.

The power business was not helping GE, as the company saw declines in revenue in recent quarters as power plants started moving more toward renewable energy to replace fossil fuels, especially coal.

Underlying Currents

Though GE’s move differs from the moves of Hitachi-ABB and Siemens, all three signify changing times in the power and utilities sector, something that is more likely to continue than abate in the near term. “These are definitely changing times for utility and energy companies," said Scott Smith, U.S. power utilities leader for Deloitte, before adding, “It is going to continue. Decarbonization of power, energy efficiency, renewables, the customer experience being different — [power companies and utilities] are going to have to adapt quickly, and I think they are."

In his 2019 U.S. Power and Utilities Industry Outlook, Smith wrote about what he calls the new normal for the sector, which features a “period of transformation and profound change driven by technological and competitive forces, as well as changing customer expectations."

“This is partly generational; younger users have become very comfortable with apps, social media, and always-on connectivity," Smith stated. “And, it’s also partly a spin-off from the increasing ubiquity of e-commerce in all spheres, for products, services and entertainment. These developments are coming from all directions, not just the big-tech giants that are household names. We’re seeing evidence of this new normal in electricity customer preferences—the desire for choice, in rate plans, in sources of delivered electricity, and in options to tap into behind-the-meter or localized sources of generation, or to integrate electricity with other home services. Commercial and industrial customers are looking to combine more cost and utilization control with opportunities to self-generate and while setting themselves and their suppliers ambitious targets to reduce emissions from their energy use."

On the generation side, Smith argued, three dominant trends have been in place for years and look to continue:

Displacement of coal-fired generation

Steady growth in natural gas

Rapid growth in wind and solar power.

Smith pointed to decarbonization as the driver but added these trends also have created opportunities for both new technologies and new business models in the sector.

On the new technologies side, Smith noted utilities are developing apps to give customers greater control over energy usage, even managing heating and cooling, lighting and window blinds from smartphones. Some utilities are entering the IoT market by offering smart appliances, such as washing machines, thermostats and hot water heaters. Wireless meters and sensors enable users to monitor energy use in real time, receive alerts if bills deviate too far from the norm, get outage alerts, and even get estimates of crew arrival times in the case of storms or widespread power failure.

“Customer retention is no longer just a question of reliability and cost," Smith said of this new normal in the power and utilities sector. “It is now a question of providing options, being connected, and allowing customers more control over their energy use."

When it comes to technology, utilities and power generators exist in an ecosystem ripe with opportunity, Smith contends. “We could point to sources of generation, with the cost performance and scalability of wind and solar continuing to improve year over year at a rapid pace; to grid operations, where smart-grid technologies provide real-time information into all aspects of grid status (not just electron flows) and where batteries are now able to provide multiple services, such as load shifting, frequency regulation and localized reserves; to distributed or localized sources of energy for which utilities can partner with customers or communities to install and operate power systems customized for specific needs," Smith wrote in his report.

Smith summed it up that all this combined is opening the door for new business models for utilities as well as market structures allowing for the entry of new, nontraditional players. He specifically cited the rise of behind-the-meter generation, community energy projects and new options for households, such as rooftop solar coupled with battery storage. “Utilities have a tremendous opportunity to develop new profitable businesses around offering services related to these developments—from installation, maintenance, and reliability services to tracking and load balancing with on-grid resources," Smith wrote.

Smith sees the sector evolving into an “entire energy tech ecosystem" that could include traditional utilities, large device makers, tech companies, infrastructure players, and small- to medium-sized venture-backed energy technology companies and a host of other business models.

Smith proclaims himself “not surprised at all" by news of power and utility sector spin-offs and realignments. In fact, he predicts that, too, is part of the new normal for the sector.

“By definition, the future is uncertain, so we know there will be surprises along the way," Smith wrote in his market report. “The electric power business has proved increasingly resilient to some kinds of surprises, like hurricanes or snowstorms. Other kinds of surprises, from technology and new competition to customer expectations, may require more deep-seated cultural change. This promises to be an interesting year."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XFV-3271-JC85-N366-00000-00Powerful Coalition Pushes Back on Anti-Tech Fervor2019-11-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYPowerful Coalition Pushes Back on Anti-Tech FervorDavid McCabe

The movement to reinterpret or change antimonopoly laws is running headlong into a legal community and interest groups just as invested in defending the status quo.

WASHINGTON - Thomas Lambert, a professor at the University of Missouri's law school, gave his former colleague Josh Hawley a warning before Mr. Hawley became a senator in January.

Mr. Lambert had been wary of Mr. Hawley's decision in 2017, as Missouri's attorney general, to open an antitrust investigation into Google, saying he didn't see the state's logic for the case. While he wished Mr. Hawley well in Congress, and said he was glad they were friends, Mr. Lambert also noted that he would continue to speak out when he disagreed with the senator's policy positions.

"And he said, 'I assume you mean on things like tech,'" Mr. Lambert recalled recently. "And I said, 'Well, mainly.'"

Their interaction highlights a deepening divide in Washington and around the country. The rising movement in the United States to consider charging the country's biggest tech companies with violating antitrust laws is running headlong into powerful and well-funded conservatives and libertarians committed to pushing back on those efforts. They include academics like Mr. Lambert; lawmakers like Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah; and groups like the Koch political network and others that are connected to the tech companies themselves.

These conservatives have largely dominated antitrust law for decades, leading to few breakups of big companies or blocked mergers. Although their ranks have dwindled somewhat in the last year, as anti-tech arguments have become more bipartisan, they still occupy positions stretching from Capitol Hill to campuses around the country.

But their power and influence have never been tested like this. The House Judiciary Committee, the Federal Trade Commission, the Justice Department and almost every state attorney general's office is investigating at least one of Silicon Valley's giants. Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, has made breaking up the tech giants and other corporate behemoths a prominent part of her presidential campaign.

Mr. Hawley, a Republican who was on the faculty at the University of Missouri's law school with Mr. Lambert, has helped lead the efforts in Congress to rethink how the government handles the big tech companies. He recently told Facebook's chief executive that he should voluntarily spin off two of his company's most valuable services.

"I firmly believe that antitrust scrutiny is warranted," Mr. Hawley said.

His actions have pushed Mr. Lambert to deliver on his earlier warning, which Mr. Hawley says he does not remember.

"This thinking is dangerous for conservatives," Mr. Lambert recently tweeted after Mr. Hawley brushed off his libertarian foes. He has also repeatedly pushed back on Big Tech's critics, recently denouncing their "snobbery and know-betterism."

At the center of the debate is a legal standard used to decide antitrust cases for decades. Judges and regulators often ask whether a dominant company is harming consumers, and usually hang their analysis on whether prices have gone up or down.

Some proponents of looking aggressively at the tech companies argue that existing laws are adequate, and that the government just needs to enforce them correctly. At least one major regulator appears sympathetic to that argument.

"I think the antitrust laws are flexible," Makan Delrahim, the top antitrust official at the Justice Department, said recently at a conference hosted by The Wall Street Journal. He added that it was important for the laws to be "vigorously enforced."

Other proponents of tough action say Congress should modify existing laws to institute a new test for monopoly cases, like factoring in the effect that a company's dominance has on workers or competitors. Still others see a solution somewhere in between.

"What has happened is the spectrum has stretched a bit," said Diana Moss, the president of the American Antitrust Institute, a group that favors strong enforcement of the traditional approach to antitrust. The organization has received funding from some tech companies.

Some of the conservatives resisting the push for antitrust action say many problems with large Silicon Valley companies have nothing to do with competition. They point, for example, to concerns about privacy and accuse Big Tech's critics of applying antitrust laws to solve a problem better suited to new data regulations.

Others say efforts to change how the government polices competition are moving too fast. Daniel Crane, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, has written a draft paper arguing that the movement to change the law "has emerged out of virtually nowhere to claim a position at the bargaining table over antitrust reform and the future of the antitrust enterprise." Thibault Schrepel, a professor at the Utrecht University School of Law, has said human flourishing "should be enhanced by applying reason to antitrust law; not fears, not feelings, not sentiments, not intuitions."

The tech giants back many similar arguments. Both Facebook and Google have financed a slate of groups that support current antitrust law.

Mr. Lambert and Mr. Schrepel are both affiliated with the International Center for Law & Economics, a research nonprofit that has received financing from Google, Amazon and Facebook, among other major companies. Geoffrey Manne, the center's leader, said that its affiliates were not paid but that some "have received honoraria for conferences or travel assistance, or grants to support their work, as have some nonaffiliates." Mr. Lambert also sits on the organization's board - a position for which, he says, he is not paid.

On Capitol Hill, Senator Lee has led the defense of existing antitrust law.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust subcommittee, Mr. Lee has held a series of hearings over the last two years where he or his witnesses have questioned the calls to rethink antitrust law. He was also quick to question the purpose of the House Judiciary Committee's inquiry into the market power of Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon, accusing the panel of trying to perform a role best left to law enforcement agencies.

Mr. Lee has been accused of letting money influence his views on the subject. The GoogleTransparency Project, a nonprofit that tracks the tech giant's connections to government, recently raised questions about whether he was influenced by donations from Google and its allies.

Mr. Lee dismissed those accusations as "paranoid fantasy." (The GoogleTransparency Project has itself received funding from Oracle, a Google competitor.)

Recently, the antitrust holdouts have found a new ally in the industrialist Charles Koch. The Koch-affiliated Americans for Prosperity ran digital ads this year urging senators and attorneys general to stick to the current approach to antitrust.

Still, many of those arguing to keep the legal status quo acknowledge that the debate has shifted, with their opponents' position becoming rapidly more mainstream.

Mr. Lee said last month that the pushback was "not necessarily going to get you a lot of favorable publicity."

The debate can take on a heated and personal tone. At a conference this spring, the soft-spoken legal academic Tim Wu responded to doubts raised by Tyler Cowen, an economist, about whether America has dangerous levels of corporate concentration by saying it was like arguing with someone who believes the earth is flat. Another speaker at the same event compared one critic of the antimonopoly position to a climate change denier.

The enmity goes both ways. Some conservatives have applied a dismissive nickname to the efforts to rethink the existing laws: hipster antitrust.

The holdouts may have one long-term advantage: For now, they say, federal judges are likely to agree with them. Antitrust doctrine is largely settled in court, and judges largely support it. Mr. Crane, the Michigan professor, noted that those judges could take a long time to change their ways.

Mr. Lee is biding his time.

"Over the last two or three years, there has been something of a shift," he said. "Only time will tell whether it proves to be a momentary fad or something more significant."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XFR-FC61-DXY4-X19R-00000-00Powerful Coalition Pushes Back on Anti-Tech Fervor2019-11-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYPowerful Coalition Pushes Back on Anti-Tech FervorDavid McCabe

The movement to reinterpret or change antimonopoly laws is running headlong into a legal community and interest groups just as invested in defending the status quo.

The movement to reinterpret or change antimonopoly laws is running headlong into a legal community and interest groups just as invested in defending the status quo.

WASHINGTON — Thomas Lambert, a professor at the University of Missouri’s law school, gave his former colleague Josh Hawley a warning before Mr. Hawley became a senator in January.

Mr. Lambert had been wary of Mr. Hawley’s decision in 2017, as Missouri’s attorney general, to open an antitrust investigation into Google, saying he didn’t see the state’s logic for the case. While he wished Mr. Hawley well in Congress, and said he was glad they were friends, Mr. Lambert also noted that he would continue to speak out when he disagreed with the senator’s policy positions.

“And he said, ‘I assume you mean on things like tech,’” Mr. Lambert recalled recently. “And I said, ‘Well, mainly.’”

Their interaction highlights a deepening divide in Washington and around the country. The rising movement in the United States to consider charging the country’s biggest tech companies with violating antitrust laws is running headlong into powerful and well-funded conservatives and libertarians committed to pushing back on those efforts. They include academics like Mr. Lambert; lawmakers like Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah; and groups like the Koch political network and others that are connected to the tech companies themselves.

These conservatives have largely dominated antitrust law for decades, leading to few breakups of big companies or blocked mergers. Although their ranks have dwindled somewhat in the last year, as anti-tech arguments have become more bipartisan, they still occupy positions stretching from Capitol Hill to campuses around the country.

But their power and influence have never been tested like this. The House Judiciary Committee, the Federal Trade Commission, the Justice Department and almost every state attorney general’s office is investigating at least one of Silicon Valley’s giants. Senator Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts, has made breaking up the tech giants and other corporate behemoths a prominent part of her presidential campaign.

Mr. Hawley, a Republican who was on the faculty at the University of Missouri’s law school with Mr. Lambert, has helped lead the efforts in Congress to rethink how the government handles the big tech companies. He recently told Facebook’s chief executive that he should voluntarily spin off two of his company’s most valuable services.

“I firmly believe that antitrust scrutiny is warranted,” Mr. Hawley said.

His actions have pushed Mr. Lambert to deliver on his earlier warning, which Mr. Hawley says he does not remember.

“This thinking is dangerous for conservatives,” Mr. Lambert recently tweeted after Mr. Hawley brushed off his libertarian foes. He has also repeatedly pushed back on Big Tech’s critics, recently   denouncing their “snobbery and know-betterism.”

At the center of the debate is a legal standard used to decide antitrust cases for decades. Judges and regulators often ask whether a dominant company is harming consumers, and usually hang their analysis on whether prices have gone up or down.

Some proponents of looking aggressively at the tech companies argue that existing laws are adequate, and that the government just needs to enforce them correctly. At least one major regulator appears sympathetic to that argument.

“I think the antitrust laws are flexible,” Makan Delrahim, the top antitrust official at the Justice Department, said recently at a conference hosted by The Wall Street Journal. He added that it was important for the laws to be “vigorously enforced.”

Other proponents of tough action say Congress should modify existing laws to institute a new test for monopoly cases, like factoring in the effect that a company’s dominance has on workers or competitors. Still others see a solution somewhere in between.

“What has happened is the spectrum has stretched a bit,” said Diana Moss, the president of the American Antitrust Institute, a group that favors strong enforcement of the traditional approach to antitrust. The organization has received funding from some tech companies.

Some of the conservatives resisting the push for antitrust action say many problems with large Silicon Valley companies have nothing to do with competition. They point, for example, to concerns about privacy and accuse Big Tech’s critics of applying antitrust laws to solve a problem better suited to new data regulations.

Others say efforts to change how the government polices competition are moving too fast. Daniel Crane, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, has written a draft paper arguing that the movement to change the law “has emerged out of virtually nowhere to claim a position at the bargaining table over antitrust reform and the future of the antitrust enterprise.” Thibault Schrepel, a professor at the Utrecht University School of Law, has said human flourishing “should be enhanced by applying reason to antitrust law; not fears, not feelings, not sentiments, not intuitions.”

The tech giants back many similar arguments. Both Facebook and Google have financed a slate of groups that support current antitrust law.

Mr. Lambert and Mr. Schrepel are both affiliated with the International Center for Law & Economics, a research nonprofit that has received financing from Google, Amazon and Facebook, among other major companies. Geoffrey Manne, the center’s leader, said that its affiliates were not paid but that some “have received honoraria for conferences or travel assistance, or grants to support their work, as have some nonaffiliates.” Mr. Lambert also sits on the organization’s board — a position for which, he says, he is not paid.

On Capitol Hill, Senator Lee has led the defense of existing antitrust law.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee’s antitrust subcommittee, Mr. Lee has held a series of hearings over the last two years where he or his witnesses have questioned the calls to rethink antitrust law. He was also quick to question the purpose of the House Judiciary Committee’s inquiry into the market power of Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon, accusing the panel of trying to perform a role best left to law enforcement agencies.

Mr. Lee has been accused of letting money influence his views on the subject. The GoogleTransparency Project, a nonprofit that tracks the tech giant’s connections to government, recently raised questions about whether he was influenced by donations from Google and its allies.

Mr. Lee dismissed those accusations as “paranoid fantasy.” (The GoogleTransparency Project has itself received funding from Oracle, a Google competitor.)

Recently, the antitrust holdouts have found a new ally in the industrialist Charles Koch. The Koch-affiliated Americans for Prosperity ran digital ads this year urging senators and attorneys general to stick to the current approach to antitrust.

Still, many of those arguing to keep the legal status quo acknowledge that the debate has shifted, with their opponents’ position becoming rapidly more mainstream.

Mr. Lee said last month that the pushback was “not necessarily going to get you a lot of favorable publicity.”

The debate can take on a heated and personal tone. At a conference this spring, the soft-spoken legal academic Tim Wu responded to doubts raised by Tyler Cowen, an economist, about whether America has dangerous levels of corporate concentration by saying it was like arguing with someone who believes the earth is flat. Another speaker at the same event compared one critic of the antimonopoly position to a climate change denier.

The enmity goes both ways. Some conservatives have applied a dismissive nickname to the efforts to rethink the existing laws: hipster antitrust.

The holdouts may have one long-term advantage: For now, they say, federal judges are likely to agree with them. Antitrust doctrine is largely settled in court, and judges largely support it. Mr. Crane, the Michigan professor, noted that those judges could take a long time to change their ways.

Mr. Lee is biding his time.

“Over the last two or three years, there has been something of a shift,” he said. “Only time will tell whether it proves to be a momentary fad or something more significant.”

PHOTOS: Senator Mike Lee of Utah (PHOTOGRAPH BY ERIN SCHAFF FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES); Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri (PHOTOGRAPH BY CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS); Makan Delrahim, an antitrust official (PHOTOGRAPH BY JEENAH MOON FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (B7)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60YG-RG81-JBCN-4026-00000-00Power hungry lawmakers are the problem, not big companies2020-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisMAINPg. 13APower hungry lawmakers are the problem, not big companiesPatrick Hedger; Patrick Hedger

Public policy often amounts to little more than a shell game, especially when it comes to taxes and regulation.

Politicians will often tell you they "only" want to raise taxes on big corporations, not middle-class families, for example. But, as advocates of lower corporate taxes routinely point out, the cost of corporate taxes and regulations doesn't come out of some vast corporate vault filled with gold coins, a la Scrooge McDuck.

Those costs are borne by the paychecks of corporations' employees and customers alike. This is why taxpayers should be alarmed by the recent and bipartisan efforts to upend our nation's antitrust laws.

Under the antitrust microscope of both Congress and state attorneys general are America's "Big Tech" companies, particularly Alphabet (Google), Amazon, Apple and Facebook. However, none of these firms neatly fit the bill for antitrust action under the current understanding of the law.

For starters, all of these companies vigorously compete with one another in multiple market segments, from advertising to hardware sales. Just last year, Facebook and Apple executives traded barbs in the media regarding the privacy practices of each other's companies.

Companies that don't compete with one another generally don't behave like this. When's the last time Coca-Cola and Goodyear publicly traded insults?

In addition, for the last half-century or so American antitrust law has been grounded in what is known as the consumer welfare standard. As its name implies, antitrust action is generally only pursued if a merger, acquisition or practice of a company or companies is harming the consumer through things like higher prices. In the case of big tech, it's hard to see where this is occurring.

Many of the consumer-facing services provided by firms such as Facebook and Google are provided at no cost to the consumer. Those businesses are fueled by advertising, which has seen collapsing prices.

One of the key complaints against Amazon? Their prices are too low. Even in hardware sales, a cornerstone of Apple's business, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that prices have been cut in half over the last decade.

Simply put, any case against these big tech firms would be very weak. You'd be hard-pressed to find an American that would have rather gone through the last few months of coronavirus-related shutdowns without being able to order cheap supplies from Amazon or connect with loved ones on Facebook from their Google Android or Apple iPhone.

Of course, nothing stops politicians looking to make names for themselves. They come from both sides of the aisle and from the federal and state governments. Most seem to be exhibiting the "first day of prison" strategy, picking a fight with the biggest brute in the yard to establish their own dominance.

The trouble is that the consumer welfare standard is standing guard and naturally must be dispatched with first.

Unmooring antitrust law from the consumer welfare standard might allow politicians to pursue their various pet grievances, from content moderation to privacy, against big tech companies.

But it would also open the floodgates on the rest of the economy.

Political actors throughout government could potentially attach all sorts of entirely peripheral strings to antitrust enforcement. Could a merger be weighed by its impact on carbon emissions? Or how many of their products are sourced from America versus overseas?

We already see shameful examples of this, with companies avoiding antitrust scrutiny through jobs guarantees and other token promises for politicians to put in press releases.

The uncertainty of political demands, let alone new regulations imposed through antitrust enforcement threats and action, would amount to an enormous cost passed directly to American consumers through higher prices and reduced economic dynamism.

There are prominent figures on both sides of the aisle eager to toss aside the shackles of the consumer welfare standard for short-term political gain. This is purely an issue of government accountability.

Regardless of the various complaints about big tech, four companies competing in various markets where prices are falling (if they aren't already zero) cannot possibly pose a bigger threat to taxpayers than granting political actors unchecked authority through a rewrite of antitrust.

Patrick Hedger is vice president of policy for the Taxpayers Protection Alliance.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4GMR-HXC0-000H-C4BC-00000-00POWER-LINE INTERNET DRAWS BACKERS, BUT IS IT TOO LATE?2005-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:17:08ZLexisNexisFinancial PagesPOWER-LINE INTERNET DRAWS BACKERS, BUT IS IT TOO LATE?

With photo.

By BOB KEEFE

Cox News Service

The idea of receiving high-speed Internet access through your electrical outlets is getting a fresh jolt of energy.

In recent weeks, big-time technology companies Google Inc., IBM Corp. and Motorola Inc. have all announced major investments or trials involving "broadband over power line" service, or BPL.

State and federal regulators, meanwhile, are moving toward easing rules for electric utilities that want to get into the high-speed Internet business.

In Texas, legislators last week were poised to pass a bill making it easier to sell Internet service over power lines. Other states, including Florida, recently took similar steps that free up municipalities such as Tallahassee that want to provide the service. Utilities such as Florida Power & Light are also considering BPL.

The federal government also has pledged its support for BPL as a way to ensure that high-speed Internet service reaches every corner of the country.

Suddenly, "there's a lot of good momentum," said Scott Bruce, managing director of Current Communications Group, which two weeks ago got a major investment _ $100 million, according to published reports _ from Google, media giant Hearst Corp. and Goldman, Sachs & Co. Current manages one of only a few commercial deployments of BPL service in the nation, near Cincinnati.

The problem is, the new momentum might be too little, too late. BPL may never become more than a niche technology limited to rural areas that can't get Internet service over TV cables or DSL telephone lines.

The idea of plugging into the World Wide Web by simply plugging into a wall socket has been around nearly as long as those two dominant broadband technologies.

With BPL, data travels over power lines from an Internet connection at a power plant to homes and offices. A customer simply plugs a computer into a wall socket or connects to a wireless transmitter mounted on a nearby power pole.

Just as significantly, BPL can give power companies unprecedented control over their power lines. With it, utilities can monitor lines for problems, read meters remotely and turn service on or off without dispatching employees.

"Yes, you can provide consumers an alternative to cable and DSL, but more importantly this is a major tool that can transform utilities and bring them into the 21st century," said Raymond Blair, vice president of BPL initiatives for IBM.

Last week, IBM announced it was partnering with Houston's CenterPoint Energy Inc. to explore BPL technology and test it in about 50 homes.

Atlanta-based utility giant Southern Co. has been considering BPL for nearly seven years. So far, the most intriguing application of the technology is for monitoring power lines and other equipment, said Leif Ericson, business development manager at Southern's telecom subsidiary.

"We don't see ourselves as a broadband service provider or some sort of other ISP," Ericson said. "Our real focus … has been on whether we might be able to overlay (BPL) to gain access to all sorts of intelligence" about existing lines and equipment.

In all, about 40 utilities around the country have run or plan to run BPL trials.

Yet with the exception of Current partner Cinergy Corp. in Ohio, no investor-owned utility has committed to selling the service yet.

Even at Cinergy, some are less than enthusiastic about the year-old experiment.

"We didn't anticipate this was going to happen overnight," said Cinergy spokeswoman Kathy Meinke. "We're continuing to move forward."

Neither Cinergy nor Current would disclose how many customers have signed up for the service. While Cinergy earlier said it would expand beyond Cincinnati and into neighboring Warren and Butler counties by next year, any expansion plans are still "yet to be determined," Meinke said.

Partly what has kept more utilities from rolling out BPL is the cost. While the power lines that can carry broadband signals are already in place, it can cost $250 or more per household for equipment that gets the signals from a home to the power pole or underground line.

That's actually relatively cheap compared to cable and DSL equipment. But utilities are notoriously tight when it comes to spending on new technology. And the last time many of them strayed from their core business and tried to offer telephone voice service, they failed miserably.

Meanwhile, early BPL technology was slow and plagued with problems. Download speeds were only a little better than dial-up service, and radio operators complained the equipment caused interference.

Newer semiconductor technology has solved interference problems, industry officials claim. At the same time, BPL now offers both downloads and uploads at 3 megabits per second _ double the speed of DSL, and faster than cable at a comparable price.

But performance may have become a moot point because of utilities' lateness to the broadband business.

Today, with cable modem and DSL available to an estimated 90 percent of all households, there really isn't much of a market left for utilities offering BPL, said Jim Penhune, an analyst with technology research company Strategy Analytics.

"I just think the timing of it is wrong," Penhune said. "Cable (and telephone) companies are so far ahead … it's a little hard for me to see how a third class of network is going to be viable."

BPL proponents disagree, of course.

The recent interest from the big tech companies shows that the technology still has plenty of promise, said Brett Kilbourne, director of regulatory services for the trade group United Power Line Council. Along with Google and IBM, Motorola in May announced it was developing BPL technology and said it was teaming up with a rural South Carolina utility to launch BPL broadband service. Last year, Mitsubishi Electric Power Products Inc. also announced it was exploring BPL technology.

At the same time, Kilbourne and other proponents say, there are still plenty of households _ 13 million by some counts _ that aren't able to get broadband access because cable and telecom companies simply don't offer it in their areas.

Also driving interest in BPL are recent court decisions that limit Internet companies' access to cable and phone lines.

Atlanta-based Earthlink Inc., for instance, has run several trials in North Carolina and elsewhere and is very encouraged, said Earthlink vice president Kevin Brand.

BPL's best shot at success may be in reaching rural households, said Jupiter Research analyst Joe Laszlo.

As a result, Laszlo predicts alternative broadband technologies including BPL, fixed wireless and satellite will triple their customers over the next five years, although they will still account for less than 3 percent of the broadband business.

Hilco Electric Cooperative north of Waco, Texas earlier this year launched a BPL pilot program that brought high-speed Internet service to its members for the first time.

Hilco general manager Gerald Lemons compared it to the introduction of electricity to rural areas in the 1930s by government-sponsored cooperatives.

"For us, it's the same principle as 60-plus years ago when investor-owned utilities wouldn't run power to rural areas because it wasn't cost-effective," Lemons said. "This is letting folks in rural areas have some of the same things that folks have in the suburbs and urban areas."

Lemons declined to say how many of the cooperative's 19,000 members have signed up for BPL service or how much they pay, citing confidentiality agreements with third-party Internet partners.

The biggest benefit for rural residents might be that BPL has finally lured other high-speed Internet providers to the area.

Shortly after Hilco began offering service in one rural neighborhood, Lemons said, telecom giant SBC Corp. started offering DSL service there for the first time.

"If you believe the objective is just to get these amenities to rural areas … we're already successful," he said.

Bob Keefe's e-mail address is bkeefe(at)coxnews.com
